Yellow highlight | Location: 1,371 Scientists refer to these exaggerated cues as supernormal stimuli. A supernormal stimulus is a heightened version of reality‚Äî

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,372 like a beak with three red dots or an egg the size of a volleyball‚Äîand it elicits a stronger response than usual.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,373 Humans are also prone to fall for exaggerated versions of reality. Junk food, for example, drives our reward systems into a frenzy. After spending hundreds of thousands of years hunting and foraging for food in the wild, the human brain has evolved to place a high value on salt, sugar, and fat. Such foods are often calorie-dense and they were quite rare when our ancient ancestors were roaming the savannah. When you don‚Äôt know where your next meal is coming from, eating as much as possible is an excellent strategy for survival.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,377 Today, however, we live in a calorie-rich environment. Food is abundant, but your brain continues to crave it like it is scarce. Placing a high value on salt, sugar, and fat is no longer advantageous to our health, but the craving persists because the brain‚Äôs reward centers have not changed for approximately fifty thousand years. The modern food industry relies on stretching our Paleolithic instincts beyond their evolutionary purpose.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,384 Entire departments are dedicated to optimizing how a product feels in your mouth‚Äîa quality known as orosensation. French fries, for example, are a potent combination‚Äîgolden brown and crunchy on the outside, light and smooth on the inside.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,389 But foods that are high in dynamic contrast keep the experience novel and interesting, encouraging you to eat more.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,393 Stephan Guyenet, a neuroscientist who specializes in eating behavior and obesity, says, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve gotten too good at pushing our own buttons.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,395 The modern food industry, and the overeating habits it has spawned, is just one example of the 2nd Law of Behavior Change: Make it attractive. The more attractive an opportunity is, the more likely it is to become habit-forming.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,397 Look around. Society is filled with highly engineered versions of reality that are more attractive than the world our ancestors evolved in. Stores feature mannequins with exaggerated hips and breasts to sell clothes. Social media delivers more ‚Äúlikes‚Äù and praise in a few minutes than we could ever get in the office or at home.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,400 Advertisements are created with a combination of ideal lighting, professional makeup, and Photoshopped edits‚Äîeven the model doesn‚Äôt look like the person in the final image. These are the supernormal stimuli of our modern world. They exaggerate features that are naturally attractive to us, and our instincts go wild as a result, driving us into excessive shopping habits, social media habits, porn habits, eating habits, and many others.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,406 Compared to nature, these pleasure-packed experiences are hard to resist. We have the brains of our ancestors but temptations they never had to face.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,408 While it is not possible to transform every habit into a supernormal stimulus, we can make any habit more enticing. To do this, we must start by understanding what a craving is and how it works. We begin by examining a biological signature that all habits share‚Äîthe dopamine spike.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,412 Scientists can track the precise moment a craving occurs by measuring a neurotransmitter called dopamine.fn1

Blue highlight | Location: 1,421 Even though dopamine was blocked, they liked the sugar just as much as before; they just didn‚Äôt want it anymore. The ability to experience pleasure remained, but without dopamine, desire died. And without desire, action stopped.11

Blue highlight | Location: 1,424 In one study, mice received a powerful hit of dopamine each time they poked their nose in a box. Within minutes, the mice developed a craving so

Blue highlight | Location: 1,425 strong they began poking their nose into the box eight hundred times per hour.12 (Humans are not so different: the average slot machine player will spin the wheel six hundred times per hour.13)

Blue highlight | Location: 1,428 Habits are a dopamine-driven feedback loop.14 Every behavior that is highly habit-forming‚Äîtaking drugs, eating junk food, playing video games, browsing social media‚Äîis associated with higher levels of dopamine. The same can be said for our most basic habitual behaviors like eating food, drinking water, having sex, and interacting socially.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,431 For years, scientists assumed dopamine was all about pleasure, but now we know it plays a central role in many neurological processes, including motivation, learning and memory, punishment and aversion, and voluntary movement.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,433 dopamine is released not only when you experience pleasure, but also when you anticipate it.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,436 Whenever you predict that an opportunity will be rewarding, your levels of dopamine spike in anticipation. And whenever dopamine rises, so does your motivation to act.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,438 It is the anticipation of a reward‚Äînot the fulfillment of it‚Äîthat gets us to take action.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,439 Interestingly, the reward system that is activated in the brain when you receive a reward is the same system that is activated when you anticipate a reward.18 This is one reason the anticipation of an experience can often feel better than the attainment of it. As a child, thinking about Christmas morning can be better than opening the gifts. As an adult, daydreaming about an upcoming vacation can be more enjoyable than actually being on vacation. Scientists refer to this as the difference between ‚Äúwanting‚Äù and ‚Äúliking.‚Äù

Orange highlight | Location: 1,459 Your brain has far more neural circuitry allocated for wanting rewards than for liking them.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,459 The wanting centers in the brain are large: the brain stem, the nucleus accumbens, the ventral tegmental area, the dorsal striatum, the amygdala, and portions of the prefrontal cortex. By comparison, the liking centers of the brain are much smaller. They are often referred to as ‚Äúhedonic hot spots‚Äù and are distributed like tiny islands throughout the brain. For instance, researchers have found that 100 percent of the nucleus accumbens is activated during wanting.19 Meanwhile, only 10 percent of the structure is activated during liking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,464 The fact that the brain allocates so much precious space to the regions responsible for craving and desire provides further evidence

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,465 of the crucial role these processes play. Desire is the engine that drives behavior. Every action is taken because of the anticipation that precedes it. It is the craving that leads to the response. These insights reveal the importance of the 2nd Law of Behavior Change. We need to make our habits attractive because it is the expectation of a rewarding experience that motivates us to act in the first place. This is where a strategy known as temptation bundling comes into play.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,493 Temptation bundling is one way to apply a psychology theory known as Premack‚Äôs Principle. Named after the work of professor David Premack, the principle states that ‚Äúmore probable behaviors will reinforce less probable behaviors.‚Äù23 In other words, even if you don‚Äôt really want to process overdue work emails, you‚Äôll become conditioned to do it if it means you get to do something you really want to do along the way.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,501 After I get my morning coffee, I will say one thing I‚Äôm grateful for that happened yesterday (need). After I say one thing I‚Äôm grateful for, I will read the news (want).

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,510 We began this chapter by discussing supernormal stimuli, which are heightened versions of reality that increase our desire to take action. Temptation bundling is one way to create a heightened version of any habit by connecting it with something you already want.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,514 The 2nd Law of Behavior Change is make it attractive. ‚ñ† The more attractive an opportunity is, the more likely it is to become habit-forming. ‚ñ† Habits are a dopamine-driven feedback loop. When dopamine rises, so does our motivation to act. ‚ñ† It is the anticipation of a reward‚Äînot the fulfillment of it‚Äîthat gets us to take action. The greater the anticipation, the greater the dopamine spike. ‚ñ† Temptation bundling is one way to make your habits more attractive. The strategy is to pair an action you want to do with an action you need to do.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,544 The Polgar sisters grew up in a culture that prioritized chess above all else‚Äîpraised them for it, rewarded them for it. In their world, an obsession with chess was normal. And as we are about to see, whatever habits are normal in your culture are among the most attractive behaviors you‚Äôll find.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,552 As Charles Darwin noted, ‚ÄúIn the long history of humankind, those who learned to collaborate and improvise most effectively have prevailed.‚Äù As a result, one of the deepest human desires is to belong. And this ancient preference exerts a powerful influence on our modern behavior.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,564 We imitate the habits of three groups in particular:2 The close. The many. The powerful.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,570 We pick up habits from the people around us. We copy the way our parents handle arguments, the way our peers flirt with one another, the way our coworkers get results. When your friends smoke pot, you give it a try, too. When your wife has a habit of double-checking that the door is locked before going to bed, you pick it up as well.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,585 One of the most effective things you can do to build better habits is to join a culture where your desired behavior is the normal behavior. New habits seem achievable when you see others doing them every day. If you are surrounded by fit people, you‚Äôre more likely to consider working out to be a common habit. If you‚Äôre surrounded by jazz lovers, you‚Äôre more likely to believe it‚Äôs reasonable to play jazz every day. Your culture sets your expectation for what is ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù Surround yourself with people who have the habits you want to have yourself. You‚Äôll rise together.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,590 To make your habits even more attractive, you can take this strategy one step further. Join a culture where (1) your desired behavior is the normal behavior and (2) you already have something in common with the group. Steve Kamb, an entrepreneur in New York City, runs a company called Nerd Fitness, which ‚Äúhelps nerds, misfits, and mutants lose weight,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,593 get strong, and get healthy.‚Äù His clients include video game lovers, movie fanatics, and average Joes who want to get in shape.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,594 but if you are already similar to the other members of the group in some way‚Äîsay, your mutual love of Star Wars‚Äîchange becomes more appealing because it feels like something people like you already do.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,596 Nothing sustains motivation better than belonging to the tribe. It transforms a personal quest into a shared one. Previously, you were on your own. Your identity was singular. You are a reader. You are a musician. You are an athlete.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,599 We are readers. We are musicians. We are cyclists. The shared identity begins to reinforce your personal identity.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,626 Whenever we are unsure how to act, we look to the group to guide our behavior. We are constantly scanning our environment and wondering, ‚ÄúWhat is everyone else doing?‚Äù We check reviews on Amazon or Yelp or TripAdvisor because we want to imitate the ‚Äúbest‚Äù buying, eating, and travel habits. It‚Äôs usually a smart strategy. There is evidence in numbers.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,629 But there can be a downside. The normal behavior of the tribe often overpowers the desired behavior of the individual. For example, one study found that when a chimpanzee learns an effective way to crack nuts open as a member of one group and then switches to a new group that uses a less effective strategy, it will avoid using the superior nut cracking method just to blend in with the rest of the chimps.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,633 The reward of being accepted is often greater than the reward of winning an argument, looking smart, or finding truth. Most days, we‚Äôd rather be wrong with the crowd than be right by ourselves.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,635 The human mind knows how to get along with others. It wants to get along with others. This is our natural mode. You can override it‚Äîyou can choose to ignore the group or to stop caring what other people think‚Äîbut it takes work. Running against the grain of your culture requires extra effort.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,637 When changing your habits means challenging the tribe, change is unattractive. When changing your habits means fitting in with the tribe, change is very attractive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,641 Historically, a person with greater power and status has access to more resources, worries less about survival, and proves to be a more attractive mate.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,643 We are drawn to behaviors that earn us respect, approval, admiration, and status. We want to be the one in the gym who can do muscle-ups or the musician who can play the hardest chord progressions or the parent with the most accomplished children because these things separate us from the crowd. Once we fit in, we start looking for ways to stand out.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,645 This is one reason we care so much about the habits of highly effective people. We try to copy the behavior of successful people because we desire success ourselves.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,649 High-status people enjoy the approval, respect, and praise of others. And that means if a behavior can get us approval, respect, and praise, we find it attractive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,650 We are also motivated to avoid behaviors that would lower our status. We trim our hedges and mow our lawn because we don‚Äôt want to be the slob of the neighborhood. When our mother comes to visit, we clean up the house because we don‚Äôt want to be judged. We are continually wondering ‚ÄúWhat will others think of me?‚Äù and altering our behavior based on the answer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,659 The culture we live in determines which behaviors are attractive to us. ‚ñ† We tend to adopt habits that are praised and approved of by our culture because we have a strong desire to fit in and belong to the tribe. ‚ñ† We tend to imitate the habits of three social groups: the close (family and friends), the many (the tribe), and the powerful (those with status and prestige). ‚ñ† One of the most effective things you can do to build better habits is to join a culture where (1) your desired behavior is the normal behavior and (2) you already have

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,665 something in common with the group. ‚ñ† The normal behavior of the tribe often overpowers the desired behavior of the individual. Most days, we‚Äôd rather be wrong with the crowd than be right by ourselves. ‚ñ† If a behavior can get us approval, respect, and praise, we find it attractive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,702 Conserve energy ‚ñ† Obtain food and water ‚ñ† Find love and reproduce ‚ñ† Connect and bond with others ‚ñ† Win social acceptance and approval ‚ñ† Reduce uncertainty ‚ñ† Achieve status and prestige

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,717 Your habits are modern-day solutions to ancient desires. New versions of old vices. The underlying motives behind human behavior remain the same. The specific habits we perform differ based on the period of history.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,721 Your current habits are not necessarily the best way to solve the problems you face; they are just the methods you learned to use. Once you associate a solution with the problem you need to solve, you keep coming back to it. Habits are all about associations. These associations determine whether we predict a habit to be worth repeating or not. As we covered

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,723 in our discussion of the 1st Law, your brain is continually absorbing information and noticing cues in the environment. Every time you perceive a cue, your brain runs a simulation and makes a prediction about what to do in the next moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,734 Two people can look at the same cigarette, and one feels the urge to smoke while the other is repulsed by the smell. The same cue can spark a good habit or a bad habit depending on your prediction. The cause of your habits is actually the prediction that precedes them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,736 These predictions lead to feelings, which is how we typically describe a craving‚Äîa feeling, a desire, an urge. Feelings and emotions transform the cues we perceive and the predictions we make into a signal that we can apply.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,741 A craving is the sense that something is missing. It is the desire to change your internal state. When the temperature falls, there is a gap between what your body is currently sensing and what it wants to be sensing. This gap between your current state and your desired state provides a reason to act.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,744 Desire is the difference between where you are now and where you want to be in the future.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,747 Our feelings and emotions tell us whether to hold steady in our current state or to make

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,747 a change. They help us decide the best course of action.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,749 As the neuroscientist Antonio Damasio explains, ‚ÄúIt is emotion that allows you to mark things as good, bad, or indifferent.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,753 In time, you learn to predict that checking social media will help you feel loved or that watching YouTube will allow you to forget your fears. Habits are attractive when we associate them with positive feelings, and we can use this insight to our advantage rather than to our detriment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,756 You can make hard habits more attractive if you can learn to associate them with a positive experience. Sometimes, all you need is a slight mind-set shift. For instance, we often talk about everything we have to do in a given day. You have to wake up early for work. You have to make another sales call for your business. You have to cook dinner for your family. Now, imagine changing just one word: You don‚Äôt ‚Äúhave‚Äù to. You ‚Äúget‚Äù to.4 You get to wake up early for work. You get to make another sales call for your business. You get to cook dinner for your family. By simply changing one word, you shift the way you view each event. You transition from seeing these behaviors as burdens and turn them into opportunities.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,763 The key point is that both versions of reality are true. You have to do those things, and you also get to do them. We can find evidence for whatever mind-set we choose.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,764 I once heard a story about a man who uses a wheelchair. When asked if it was difficult being confined, he responded, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not confined to my wheelchair‚ÄîI am liberated by it.5 If it wasn‚Äôt for my wheelchair, I would be bed-bound and never able to leave my house.‚Äù This shift in perspective completely transformed how he lived each day.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,767 Reframing your habits to highlight their benefits rather than their drawbacks is a fast and lightweight way to reprogram your mind and make a habit seem more attractive.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,773 money you save this month increases your purchasing power next month.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,777 Pregame jitters. Many people feel anxious before delivering a big presentation or competing in an important event. They experience quicker breathing, a faster heart rate, heightened arousal. If we interpret these feelings negatively, then we feel threatened and tense up. If we interpret these feelings positively, then we can respond with fluidity and grace. You can reframe ‚ÄúI am nervous‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am excited and I‚Äôm getting an adrenaline rush to help me concentrate.‚Äù7

Blue highlight | Location: 1,782 with a particular habit or situation. If you want to take it a step further, you can create a motivation ritual. You simply practice associating your habits with something you enjoy, then you can use that cue whenever you need a bit of motivation.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,786 Ed Latimore, a boxer and writer from Pittsburgh, benefited from a similar strategy without knowing it.8 ‚ÄúOdd realization,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúMy focus and concentration goes up just by putting my headphones [on] while writing. I don‚Äôt even have to play any music.‚Äù Without realizing it, he was conditioning himself. In the beginning, he put his headphones on, played some music he enjoyed, and did focused work. After doing it five, ten, twenty times, putting his headphones on became a cue that he automatically associated with increased focus. The craving followed naturally.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,792 While it physically warmed me up to play, more importantly, it put me in the right mental state. I began to associate my pregame ritual with feeling competitive and focused.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,799 Once established, you can break it out anytime you need to change your emotional state. Stressed at work? Take three deep breaths and smile. Sad about life? Three deep breaths and smile. Once a habit has been built, the cue can prompt a craving, even if it has little to do with the original situation.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,801 The key to finding and fixing the causes of your bad habits is to reframe the associations you have about them. It‚Äôs not easy, but if you can reprogram your predictions, you can transform a hard habit into an attractive one.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,807 Your habits are modern-day solutions to ancient desires.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,811 Habits are attractive when we associate them with positive feelings and unattractive when we associate them with negative feelings. Create a motivation ritual by doing something you enjoy immediately before a difficult habit.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,842 ON THE FIRST day of class, Jerry Uelsmann, a professor at the University of Florida, divided his film photography students into two groups. Everyone on the left side of the classroom, he explained, would be in the ‚Äúquantity‚Äù group. They would be graded solely on the amount of work they produced. On the final day of class, he would tally the number of photos submitted by each student. One hundred photos would rate an A, ninety photos a B, eighty photos a C, and so on.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,846 Meanwhile, everyone on the right side of the room would be in the ‚Äúquality‚Äù group. They would be graded only on the excellence of their work. They would only need to produce one photo during the semester, but to get an A, it had to be a nearly perfect image. At the end of the term, he was surprised to find that all the best photos were produced by the quantity group. During the semester, these students were busy taking photos, experimenting with composition and lighting, testing out various methods in the darkroom, and learning from their mistakes. In the process of creating hundreds of photos, they honed their skills. Meanwhile, the quality group sat around speculating about perfection. In the end, they had little to show for their efforts other than unverified theories and one mediocre photo.

Pink highlight | Location: 1,853 It is easy to get bogged down trying to find the optimal plan for change: the fastest way to lose weight, the best program to build muscle, the perfect idea for a side hustle. We are so focused on figuring out the best approach that

Pink highlight | Location: 1,855 we never get around to taking action. As Voltaire once wrote, ‚ÄúThe best is the enemy of the good.‚Äù2

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,856 I refer to this as the difference between being in motion and taking action. The two ideas sound similar, but they‚Äôre not the same. When you‚Äôre in motion, you‚Äôre planning and strategizing and learning. Those are all good things, but they don‚Äôt produce a result.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,858 Action, on the other hand, is the type of behavior that will deliver an outcome. If I outline twenty ideas for articles I want to write, that‚Äôs motion. If I actually sit down and write an article, that‚Äôs action. If I search for a better diet plan and read a few books on the topic, that‚Äôs motion. If I actually eat a healthy meal, that‚Äôs action.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,867 It‚Äôs easy to be in motion and convince yourself that you‚Äôre still making progress. You think, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got conversations going with four potential clients right now. This is good. We‚Äôre moving in the right direction.‚Äù Or, ‚ÄúI brainstormed some ideas for that book I want to write. This is coming together.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,871 When preparation becomes a form of procrastination, you need to change something.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,872 If you want to master a habit, the key is to start with repetition, not perfection. You don‚Äôt need to map out every feature of a new habit. You just need to practice it. This is the first takeaway of the 3rd Law: you just need to get your reps in.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,877 Neuroscientists call this long-term potentiation, which refers to the strengthening of connections between neurons in the brain based on recent patterns of activity.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,886 When scientists analyzed the brains of taxi drivers in London, they found that the hippocampus‚Äîa region of the brain involved in spatial memory‚Äîwas significantly larger in their subjects than in non‚Äìtaxi drivers.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,896 Each time you repeat an action, you are activating a particular neural circuit associated with that habit. This means that simply putting in your reps is one of the most critical steps you can take to encoding a new habit.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,899 All habits follow a similar trajectory from effortful practice to automatic behavior, a process known as automaticity. Automaticity is the ability to perform a behavior without thinking about each step, which occurs when the nonconscious mind takes over.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,929 The 3rd Law of Behavior Change is make it easy. ‚ñ† The most effective form of learning is practice, not planning.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,931 Focus on taking action, not being in motion. ‚ñ† Habit formation is the process by which a behavior becomes progressively more automatic through repetition. ‚ñ† The amount of time you have been performing a habit is not as important as the number of times you have performed it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,961 Maybe if you really wanted it, you‚Äôd actually do it. But the truth is, our real motivation is to be lazy and to do what is convenient. And despite what the latest productivity best seller will tell you, this is a smart strategy, not a dumb one.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,973 Look at any behavior that fills up much of your life and you‚Äôll see that it can be performed with very low levels of motivation. Habits like scrolling on our phones, checking email, and watching television steal so much of our time because they can be performed almost without effort. They are remarkably convenient.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,978 This is why it is crucial to make your habits so easy that you‚Äôll do them even when

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,979 you don‚Äôt feel like it. If you can make your good habits more convenient, you‚Äôll be more likely to follow through on them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,993 One of the most effective ways to reduce the friction associated with your habits is to practice environment design.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,008 I like to refer to this strategy as addition by subtraction.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,039 ‚Ä¶. People think I work hard but I‚Äôm actually really lazy. I‚Äôm just proactively lazy. It gives you so much time back.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,059 Whenever possible, I leave my phone in a different room until lunch. When it‚Äôs right next to me,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,069 ‚ÄúHow can we design a world where it‚Äôs easy to do what‚Äôs right?‚Äù Redesign your life so the actions that matter most are also the actions that are easiest to do.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,072 Human behavior follows the Law of Least Effort. We will naturally gravitate toward the option that requires the least amount of work. ‚ñ† Create an environment where doing the right thing is as easy as possible. ‚ñ† Reduce the friction associated with good behaviors. When friction is low, habits are easy. ‚ñ† Increase the friction associated with bad behaviors. When friction is high, habits are difficult. ‚ñ† Prime your environment to make future actions easier.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,086 ritual. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a simple act, but doing it the same way each morning habitualizes it‚Äî

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,090 Researchers estimate that 40 to 50 percent of our actions on any given day are done out of habit.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,092 This is already a substantial percentage, but the true influence of your habits is even greater than these numbers suggest. Habits are automatic choices that influence the conscious

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,093 decisions that follow. Yes, a habit can be completed in just a few seconds, but it can also shape the actions that you take for minutes or hours afterward.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,094 Habits are like the entrance ramp to a highway. They lead you down a path and, before you know it, you‚Äôre speeding toward the next behavior.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,095 It seems to be easier to continue what you are already doing than to start doing something different.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,102 the ritual is changing into my workout clothes. If I change clothes, I know the workout will happen. Everything that follows‚Äîdriving to the gym, deciding which exercises to do, stepping under the bar‚Äîis easy once I‚Äôve taken the first step.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,104 Every day, there are a handful of moments that deliver an outsized impact. I refer to these little choices as decisive moments.4 The moment you decide between ordering takeout or cooking dinner. The moment you choose between driving your car or riding your bike. The moment you decide between starting your homework or grabbing the video game controller. These choices are a fork in the road.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,107 Decisive moments set the options available to your future self.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,110 Your options are constrained by

Blue highlight | Location: 2,110 what‚Äôs available. They are shaped by the first choice.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,116 We are limited by where our habits lead us. This is why mastering the decisive moments throughout your day is so important. Each day is made up of many moments, but it is really a few habitual choices that determine the path you take. These little choices stack up,

Blue highlight | Location: 2,118 Habits are the entry point, not the end point. They are the cab, not the gym.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,122 Two-Minute Rule, which states, ‚ÄúWhen you start a new habit, it should take less than two minutes to do.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 2,125 ‚ñ† ‚ÄúRead before bed each night‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúRead one page.‚Äù ‚ñ† ‚ÄúDo thirty minutes of yoga‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúTake out my yoga mat.‚Äù ‚ñ† ‚ÄúStudy for class‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúOpen my notes.‚Äù ‚ñ† ‚ÄúFold the laundry‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúFold one pair of socks.‚Äù ‚ñ† ‚ÄúRun three miles‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúTie my running shoes.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 2,137 Your goal might be to run a marathon, but your gateway habit is to put on your running shoes.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,142 Instead of trying to engineer a perfect habit from the start, do the easy thing on a more consistent basis. You have to standardize before you can optimize.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,145 The more you ritualize the beginning of a process, the more likely it becomes that you can slip into the state of deep focus that is required to do great things. By doing the same warm-up before every workout, you make it easier to get into a state of peak performance.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,147 By following the same creative ritual, you make it easier to get into the hard work of creating.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,147 consistent power-down habit, you make it easier to get to bed at a reasonable time each night.6 You may not be able to automate the whole process, but you can make the first action mindless. Make it easy to start and the rest will follow.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,159 Journaling provides another

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,159 example. Nearly everyone can benefit from getting their thoughts out of their head and onto paper, but most people give up after a few

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,165 Strategies like this work for another reason, too: they reinforce the identity you want to build. If you show up at the gym five days in a row‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs just for two minutes‚Äîyou are casting votes for your new identity. You‚Äôre not worried about getting in shape. You‚Äôre focused on becoming the type of person who doesn‚Äôt miss

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,167 workouts. You‚Äôre taking the smallest action that confirms the type of person you want to be.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,182 Habits can be completed in a few seconds but continue to impact your behavior for minutes or hours afterward. ‚ñ† Many habits occur at decisive moments‚Äîchoices that are like a fork in the road‚Äîand either send you in the direction of a productive day or an unproductive one. ‚ñ† The Two-Minute Rule states,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,186 ‚ÄúWhen you start a new habit, it should take less than two minutes to do.‚Äù ‚ñ† The more you ritualize the beginning of a process, the more likely it becomes that you can slip into the state of deep focus that is required to do great things. ‚ñ† Standardize before you optimize. You can‚Äôt improve a habit that doesn‚Äôt exist.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,199 Sometimes success is less about making good habits easy and more about making bad habits hard. This is an inversion of the 3rd Law of Behavior Change: make it difficult. If you find yourself continually struggling to follow through on your plans, then you can take a page from Victor Hugo and make

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,201 your bad habits more difficult by creating what psychologists call a commitment device. A commitment device is a choice you make in the present that controls your actions in the future.2 It is a way to lock in future behavior, bind you to good habits, and restrict you from bad ones. When Victor Hugo shut his clothes away so he could focus on writing, he was creating a commitment device.4 fn2

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,212 Commitment devices are useful because they enable you to take advantage of good intentions before you can fall victim to temptation. Whenever I‚Äôm looking to cut calories, for example, I will ask the

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,214 waiter to split my meal and box half of it to go before the meal is served. If I waited until the meal came out and told myself ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just eat half,‚Äù it would never work.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,215 The key is to change the task such that it requires more work to get out of the good habit than to get started on

Blue highlight | Location: 2,218 effort and may cost money. Commitment devices increase the odds that you‚Äôll do the right thing in the future by making bad habits difficult in the present. However, we can do even better. We can make good habits inevitable and bad habits impossible.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,236 The best way to break a bad habit is to make it impractical to do. Increase the friction until you don‚Äôt even have the option to act. The brilliance of the cash register was that it automated ethical behavior by making stealing practically impossible. Rather than trying to change the employees, it made the preferred behavior automatic.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,272 As mathematician and philosopher Alfred North Whitehead wrote, ‚ÄúCivilization advances by extending the number of operations we can perform without thinking about them.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 2,277 Technology creates a level of convenience that enables you to act on your smallest whims and desires. At the mere suggestion of hunger, you can have food delivered to your door. At the slightest hint of boredom, you can get lost in the vast expanse of social media.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,278 When the effort required to act on your desires becomes effectively zero, you can find yourself slipping into whatever impulse arises at the moment. The downside of automation is that we can find ourselves jumping from easy task to easy task without making time for more difficult, but ultimately more rewarding, work.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,284 (I‚Äôm not the only one. The average person spends over two hours per day on social media.8 What could you do with an extra six hundred hours per year?)

Blue highlight | Location: 2,285 During the year I was writing

Blue highlight | Location: 2,286 this book, I experimented with a new time management strategy. Every Monday, my assistant would reset the passwords on all my social media accounts, which logged me out on each device. All week I worked without distraction. On Friday, she would send me the new passwords.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,292 After I removed the mental candy from my environment, it became much easier to eat the healthy stuff.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,294 By utilizing commitment devices, strategic onetime decisions, and technology, you can create an environment of inevitability‚Äî

Blue highlight | Location: 2,295 a space where good habits are not just an outcome you hope for but an outcome that is virtually guaranteed.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,298 The inversion of the 3rd Law of Behavior Change is make it difficult. ‚ñ† A commitment device is a choice you make in the present that locks in better behavior in the future.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,301 ‚ñ† The ultimate way to lock in future behavior is to automate your habits. ‚ñ† Onetime choices‚Äîlike buying a better mattress or enrolling in an automatic savings plan‚Äîare single actions that automate your future habits and deliver increasing returns over time. ‚ñ† Using technology to automate your habits is the most reliable and effective way to guarantee the right behavior.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,320 Prime the environment. Prepare your environment to make future actions easier.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,334 and your bad habits. 3.7 Use a commitment device. Restrict your future choices to the ones that benefit you.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,364 ‚ÄúI see the goal of handwashing promotion not as behavior change but as habit adoption,‚Äù Luby said.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,366 The marketing team at Procter & Gamble talked about trying to create a positive handwashing experience.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 2,374 It was a powerful example of the fourth and final Law of Behavior Change: make it satisfying.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,375 We are more likely to repeat a behavior when the experience is satisfying. This is entirely logical. Feelings of pleasure‚Äîeven minor ones like washing your hands with soap that smells nice and lathers well‚Äîare signals that tell the brain: ‚ÄúThis feels good. Do this again, next time.‚Äù Pleasure teaches your brain that a behavior is worth remembering and repeating.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,383 Tasty flavors and the feeling of a fresh mouth provided little bits of immediate reinforcement and made the product satisfying to use. Consumption skyrocketed, and Wrigley became the largest chewing gum company in the world.9

Blue highlight | Location: 2,393 Stories like these are evidence of the Cardinal Rule of Behavior Change: What is rewarded is repeated. What is punished is avoided. You learn what to do in the future based on what you were rewarded for doing (or punished for doing) in the past. Positive emotions cultivate habits. Negative emotions destroy them.

Orange highlight | Location: 2,395 The first three laws of behavior change‚Äîmake it obvious, make it attractive, and make it easy‚Äîincrease the odds that a behavior will be performed this time. The fourth law of behavior change‚Äîmake it satisfying‚Äîincreases the odds that a behavior will be repeated next time. It completes the habit loop. But there is a trick. We are not looking for just any type of satisfaction. We are looking for immediate satisfaction.

Orange highlight | Location: 2,402 You are constantly focused on the present or the very near future. You live in what scientists call an immediate-return environment

Blue highlight | Location: 2,406 You live in what scientists call a delayed-return environment because you can work for years before your actions deliver the intended payoff.

Orange highlight | Location: 2,407 The human brain did not evolve for life in a delayed-return environment. The earliest remains of modern humans,

Blue highlight | Location: 2,408 known as Homo sapiens sapiens, are approximately two hundred thousand years old.12 These were the first humans to have a brain relatively similar to ours. In particular, the neocortex‚Äîthe newest part of the brain and the region responsible for higher functions like language‚Äîwas roughly the same size two hundred thousand years ago as today. You are walking around with the same hardware as your Paleolithic ancestors.13

Blue highlight | Location: 2,413 the last five hundred years or so‚Äîthat society has shifted to a predominantly delayed-return environment.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,416 The world has changed much in recent years, but human nature has changed little.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,420 And after thousands of generations in an immediate-return environment, our brains evolved to prefer quick payoffs to long-term ones.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,421 Behavioral economists refer to this tendency as time inconsistency. That is, the way your brain evaluates rewards is inconsistent across time.fn2 You value the present more than the future.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,425 Why would someone smoke if they know it increases the risk of lung cancer? Why would someone overeat when they know it increases their

Blue highlight | Location: 2,426 risk of obesity? Why would someone have unsafe sex if they know it can result in sexually transmitted disease?

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,427 Once you understand how the brain prioritizes rewards, the answers become clear: the consequences of bad habits are delayed while the rewards are immediate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,431 Every habit produces multiple outcomes across time. Unfortunately, these outcomes are often misaligned.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,434 ‚ÄúIt almost always happens that when the immediate consequence is favorable, the later consequences are disastrous, and vice versa ‚Ä¶.18 Often, the sweeter the first fruit of a habit, the more bitter are its later fruits.‚Äù

Pink highlight | Location: 2,440 However, when the moment of decision arrives, instant gratification usually wins.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,446 Our preference for instant gratification reveals an important truth about success: because of how we are wired, most people will spend all day chasing quick hits of satisfaction. The road less traveled is the road of delayed gratification. If you‚Äôre willing to wait for the rewards, you‚Äôll face less competition and often get a bigger payoff. As the saying goes, the last mile is always the least crowded.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,450 People who are better at delaying gratification have higher SAT scores, lower levels of substance abuse, lower likelihood of obesity, better responses to stress, and superior social skills.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,456 Thankfully, it‚Äôs possible to train yourself to delay gratification‚Äîbut you need to work with the grain of human nature, not

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,457 against it. The best way to do this is to add a little bit of immediate pleasure to the habits that pay off in the long-run and a little bit of immediate pain to ones that don‚Äôt.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,459 The vital thing in getting a habit to stick is to feel successful‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs in a small way. The feeling of success is a signal that your habit paid off and that the work was worth the effort.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,466 What we‚Äôre really talking about here‚Äîwhen we‚Äôre discussing immediate rewards‚Äîis the ending of a behavior. The ending of any experience is vital because we tend to remember it more than other

Pink highlight | Location: 2,468 The best approach is to use reinforcement, which refers to the process of using an immediate reward to increase the rate of a behavior.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,469 Habit stacking, which we covered in Chapter 5, ties your habit to an immediate cue, which makes it obvious when to start. Reinforcement ties your habit to an immediate reward, which makes it satisfying when you finish.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,477 The immediate reward of seeing yourself save money toward the leather

Pink highlight | Location: 2,478 jacket feels a lot better than being deprived. You are making it satisfying to do nothing.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,487 Eventually, as intrinsic rewards like a better mood, more energy, and reduced stress kick in, you‚Äôll become less concerned with chasing the secondary reward. The identity itself becomes the reinforcer. You do it because it‚Äôs who you are and it feels good to be you. The more a habit becomes part of your life, the less you need outside encouragement to follow through. Incentives can start a habit. Identity sustains a habit.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,492 In summary, a habit needs to be enjoyable for it to last. Simple bits of reinforcement‚Äîlike soap that smells great or toothpaste that has a refreshing mint flavor or seeing $50 hit your savings account‚Äîcan offer the immediate pleasure you need to enjoy a habit. And change is easy when it is enjoyable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,496 ‚ñ† The 4th Law of Behavior Change is make it satisfying. ‚ñ† We are more likely to repeat a behavior when the experience is satisfying. ‚ñ† The human brain evolved to prioritize immediate rewards over delayed rewards. ‚ñ† The Cardinal Rule of Behavior Change: What is immediately rewarded is repeated. What is immediately punished is avoided. ‚ñ† To get a habit to stick you need to feel immediately successful‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs in a small

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,502 way. ‚ñ† The first three laws of behavior change‚Äîmake it obvious, make it attractive, and make it easy‚Äîincrease the odds that a behavior will be performed this time. The fourth law of behavior change‚Äîmake it satisfying‚Äîincreases the odds that a behavior will be repeated next time.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,510 Dyrsmid began each morning with two jars on his desk. One was filled with 120 paper clips. The other was empty. As soon as he settled in each day, he would make a sales call. Immediately after, he would move one paper clip from the full jar

Pink highlight | Location: 2,511 to the empty jar and the process would begin again. ‚ÄúEvery morning I would start with 120 paper clips in one jar and I would keep dialing the phone until I had moved them all to the second jar,‚Äù he told me.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,520 Visual measurement comes in many forms: food journals, workout logs, loyalty punch cards, the progress bar on a software download, even the page numbers in a book. But perhaps the best way to measure your progress is with a habit tracker.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,525 Countless people have tracked their habits, but perhaps the most famous was Benjamin Franklin.2 Beginning at age twenty, Franklin carried

Pink highlight | Location: 2,527 a small booklet everywhere he went and used it to track thirteen personal virtues. This list included goals like ‚ÄúLose no time. Be always employed in something useful‚Äù and ‚ÄúAvoid trifling conversation.‚Äù At the end of each day, Franklin would open his booklet and record his progress.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,532 ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt break the chain‚Äù is a powerful mantra. Don‚Äôt break the chain of sales calls and you‚Äôll build a successful book of business. Don‚Äôt break the chain of workouts and you‚Äôll get fit faster than you‚Äôd expect. Don‚Äôt break the chain of creating every day and you will end up

Pink highlight | Location: 2,535 Habit tracking is powerful because it leverages multiple Laws of Behavior Change. It simultaneously makes a behavior obvious, attractive, and satisfying.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,558 Habit tracking also helps keep your eye on the ball: you‚Äôre focused on the process rather than the result. You‚Äôre not fixated on getting six-pack abs, you‚Äôre just trying to keep the streak alive and become the type of person who doesn‚Äôt miss workouts.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,560 In summary, habit tracking (1) creates a visual cue that can remind you to act, (2) is inherently motivating because you see the progress you are making and don‚Äôt want to lose it, and (3) feels satisfying

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,562 whenever you record another successful instance of your habit.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,562 Furthermore, habit tracking provides visual proof that you are casting votes for the type of person you wish to become, which is a delightful form of immediate and intrinsic gratification.fn1

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,597 The first mistake is never the one that ruins you.7 It is the spiral of repeated mistakes that follows. Missing once is an accident.8 Missing twice is the start of a new habit.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,600 But when successful people fail, they rebound quickly. The breaking of a habit doesn‚Äôt matter if the reclaiming of it is fast.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,606 ‚ÄúThe first rule of compounding: Never interrupt it unnecessarily.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,610 the workout. It‚Äôs about being the type of person who doesn‚Äôt miss workouts. It‚Äôs easy to train when you feel good, but it‚Äôs crucial to show up when you don‚Äôt feel like it‚Äîeven if you do less than you hope. Going to the gym for five minutes may not improve your performance, but it reaffirms your identity. The

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,628 we optimize for what we measure. When we choose the wrong measurement, we get the wrong behavior.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,629 This is sometimes referred to as Goodhart‚Äôs Law. Named after the economist Charles Goodhart, the principle states, ‚ÄúWhen a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.‚Äù9 Measurement is only useful when it guides you and adds context to a larger picture, not when it consumes you. Each number is simply one piece of feedback in the

Blue highlight | Location: 2,645 ‚ñ† One of the most satisfying feelings is the feeling of making progress. ‚ñ† A habit tracker is a simple way to measure whether you did a habit‚Äîlike marking an X on a calendar. ‚ñ† Habit trackers and other visual forms of measurement can make your habits satisfying by providing clear evidence of your progress. ‚ñ† Don‚Äôt break the chain. Try to keep your habit streak alive. ‚ñ† Never miss twice. If you miss one day, try to get back on track as quickly as possible. ‚ñ† Just because you can measure something doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the most important thing.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,684 In general, the more local, tangible, concrete, and immediate the consequence, the

Blue highlight | Location: 2,684 more likely it is to influence individual behavior.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,685 Thankfully, there is a straightforward way to add an immediate cost to any bad habit: create a habit contract.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,809 choose the right field of competition. This is just as true with habit change as it is with sports and business.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,810 Habits are easier to perform, and more satisfying to stick with, when they align with your natural inclinations and abilities. Like Michael Phelps in the pool or Hicham El Guerrouj on the track, you want to play a game where the odds are in your favor.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,819 This is true not just for physical characteristics but for mental ones as well. I‚Äôm smart if you ask me about habits and human behavior; not so much when it comes to knitting, rocket propulsion, or guitar chords. Competence is highly dependent on context.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,830 Indeed, beneath the surface of every behavior. Genes have been shown to influence everything from the number of hours you spend watching television to your likelihood to marry or divorce to your tendency to get addicted to drugs, alcohol, or nicotine.8 There‚Äôs a strong genetic component to how obedient or rebellious you are when facing authority, how vulnerable or resistant you are to stressful events, how proactive or reactive you tend to be, and even how captivated or bored you feel during sensory experiences like attending a concert.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,835 Robert Plomin,

Blue highlight | Location: 2,835 King‚Äôs College in London, told me, ‚ÄúIt is now at the point where we have stopped testing to see if traits have a genetic component because we literally can‚Äôt find a single one that isn‚Äôt influenced by our genes.‚Äù10

Blue highlight | Location: 2,839 The most proven scientific analysis of personality traits is known as the ‚ÄúBig Five,‚Äù which breaks them down into five spectrums of behavior.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,840 Openness to experience: from curious and inventive on one end to cautious and consistent on the other. Conscientiousness: organized and efficient to easygoing and spontaneous. Extroversion: outgoing and energetic to solitary and reserved (you likely know them as extroverts vs.¬†introverts). Agreeableness: friendly and compassionate to challenging and detached. Neuroticism: anxious and sensitive to confident,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,850 natural antidepressant.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,852 As a third example, consider neuroticism, which is a personality trait all people possess to various degrees. People who are high in neuroticism tend to be anxious and worry more than others. This trait has been

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,853 linked to hypersensitivity of the amygdala, the portion of the brain responsible for noticing threats.14 In other words, people who are more sensitive to negative cues in their environment are more likely to score high in neuroticism.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,872 Learning to play a game where the odds are in your favor is critical for maintaining motivation and feeling successful. In theory, you can enjoy almost anything. In practice, you are more likely to enjoy the things that come easily to you. People who are talented in a particular area tend to be more competent at that task and are then praised for doing a good job. They stay energized because they are making progress where others have failed, and because they get rewarded with better pay and bigger opportunities, which not only makes them happier but also propels them to produce even higher-quality work. It‚Äôs a virtuous cycle.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,877 Pick the right habit and progress is easy. Pick the wrong habit and life is a struggle.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,878 In many cases, when people pick the wrong habit, it simply means they picked a habit that was too difficult.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,882 The most common approach is trial and error. Of course, there‚Äôs a problem with this strategy: life is short. You don‚Äôt have time to try every career, date every eligible bachelor, or play every musical instrument. Thankfully, there is an effective way to manage this conundrum, and it is known as the explore/exploit trade-off.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,885 activity, there should be a period of exploration. In relationships, it‚Äôs called dating. In college, it‚Äôs called the liberal arts. In business, it‚Äôs called split testing. The goal is to try out many possibilities, research a broad range of ideas, and cast a wide net.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,890 In the long-run it is probably most effective to work on the strategy that seems to deliver the best results about 80 to 90 percent of the time and keep exploring with the remaining 10 to 20 percent. Google famously asks employees to spend 80 percent of the workweek on their official job and 20 percent on projects of their choice, which has led to the creation of

Pink highlight | Location: 2,892 blockbuster products like AdWords and Gmail.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,897 As you explore different options, there are a series of questions you can ask yourself to continually narrow in on the habits and areas that will be most satisfying to you:

Pink highlight | Location: 2,899 What feels like fun to me, but work to others? The mark of whether you are made for a task is not whether you love it but whether you can handle the pain of the task easier than most people.

Pink highlight | Location: 2,900 When are you enjoying yourself while other

Pink highlight | Location: 2,900 people are complaining? The work that hurts you less than it hurts others is the work you were made to do.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,901 What makes me lose track of time? Flow is the mental state you enter when you are so focused on the task at hand that the rest of the world fades away.19 This blend of happiness and peak performance is what athletes and performers experience when they are ‚Äúin the zone.‚Äù It is nearly impossible to experience a flow state and not find the task satisfying at least to some degree.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,905 Where do I get greater returns than the average person? We are continually comparing ourselves to those around us, and a behavior is more likely to be satisfying when the comparison is in our favor. When I started writing at jamesclear.com, my email list grew very quickly. I wasn‚Äôt quite sure what I was doing well, but I knew that results seemed to be coming faster for me than

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,908 for some of my colleagues, which motivated me to keep writing.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,909 What comes naturally to me? For just a moment, ignore what you have been taught. Ignore what society has told you. Ignore what others expect of you. Look inside yourself and ask, ‚ÄúWhat feels natural to me? When have I felt alive? When have I felt like the real me?‚Äù No internal judgments or people-pleasing. No second-guessing or self-criticism. Just feelings of engagement and enjoyment. Whenever you feel authentic and genuine, you are headed in the right direction.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,913 To be honest, some of this process is just luck. Michael Phelps and Hicham El Guerrouj were lucky to be born with a rare set of abilities that are highly valued by society and to be placed in the ideal environment for those abilities.

Blue highlight | Location: 2,916 If you can‚Äôt find a game where the odds are stacked in your favor, create one. Scott Adams, the cartoonist behind Dilbert, says, ‚ÄúEveryone has at least a few areas in which they could be in the top 25% with some effort.20 In my case, I can draw better than most people, but I‚Äôm hardly an artist. And I‚Äôm not any funnier than the average standup comedian who never makes it big, but I‚Äôm funnier than most people. The magic is that few people can draw well and write jokes. It‚Äôs the combination of the two that makes what I do so rare. And when you add in my business background, suddenly I had a topic that few cartoonists could hope to understand without living it.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,922 When you can‚Äôt win by being better, you can win by being different. By combining your skills, you reduce the level of competition, which makes it easier to stand out. You can shortcut the need for a genetic advantage (or for years of practice) by rewriting the rules. A good player works hard to win the game everyone else is playing. A great player creates a new game that favors their strengths and avoids

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,925 their weaknesses.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,929 Specialization is a powerful way to overcome the ‚Äúaccident‚Äù of bad genetics. The more you master a specific skill, the harder it becomes for others to compete with you.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,931 strength. Even if you‚Äôre not the most naturally gifted, you can often win by being the best in a very narrow category.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,932 Boiling water will soften a potato but harden an egg. You can‚Äôt control whether you‚Äôre a potato or an egg, but you can decide to play a game where it‚Äôs better to be hard or soft. If you can find a more favorable environment, you can transform the situation from one where the odds are against you to one where they are in your favor.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,936 Our genes do not eliminate the need for hard work. They clarify it. They tell us what to work hard on. Once we realize our strengths, we know where to spend our time and energy. We know which types of opportunities to look for and which types of challenges to avoid. The better we understand our nature, the better our strategy can be.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,940 fulfilling your own potential than comparing yourself to someone else. The fact that you have a natural limit to any specific ability has nothing to do with whether you are reaching the ceiling of your capabilities. People get so caught up in the fact that they have limits that they rarely exert the effort required to get close to them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,942 Furthermore, genes can‚Äôt make you successful if you‚Äôre not doing the work. Yes, it‚Äôs possible that the ripped trainer at the gym has better genes, but if you haven‚Äôt put in the same reps, it‚Äôs impossible to say if you have been dealt a better or worse genetic hand. Until you work as hard as those you admire, don‚Äôt explain away their success as luck. In summary, one of the best ways to ensure your habits remain satisfying over the long-run is to pick behaviors that align with your personality and skills. Work hard on the things that come easy.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,948 The secret to maximizing your odds of success is to choose the right field of competition. ‚ñ† Pick the right habit and progress is easy. Pick the wrong habit and life is a struggle. ‚ñ† Genes cannot be easily changed, which means they provide a powerful advantage in favorable circumstances and a serious disadvantage in unfavorable circumstances. ‚ñ† Habits are easier when they align with your natural abilities. Choose the habits that best suit you. ‚ñ† Play a game that favors your strengths. If you can‚Äôt find a game that favors you, create one. ‚ñ† Genes do not eliminate the need for hard work. They clarify it. They tell us what to work hard on.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,980 While there is still much to learn, one of the most consistent findings is that the way to maintain motivation and achieve peak levels of desire is to work on tasks of ‚Äújust manageable difficulty.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 2,982 The human brain loves a challenge, but only if it is within an optimal zone of difficulty. If you love tennis and try to play a serious match against a four-year-old, you will quickly become bored. It‚Äôs too easy. You‚Äôll win every point. In contrast, if you play a professional tennis player like Roger Federer or Serena Williams, you will quickly lose motivation because the match is too difficult.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,988 The Goldilocks Rule states that humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are right on the edge of their current abilities. Not too hard. Not too easy. Just right.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,993 When you‚Äôre starting a new habit, it‚Äôs important to keep the behavior as easy as possible so you can stick with it even when conditions aren‚Äôt perfect. This is an idea we covered in detail while discussing the 3rd Law of Behavior Change.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,003 A flow state is the experience of being ‚Äúin the zone‚Äù and fully immersed in an activity. Scientists have tried to quantify this feeling. They found that to achieve a state of flow, a task must be roughly 4 percent beyond your current ability.5 In real life it‚Äôs typically not feasible to quantify the difficulty of an action in this way, but the core idea of the Goldilocks Rule remains: working on challenges of just manageable difficulty‚Äîsomething on the perimeter of your ability‚Äîseems crucial for maintaining motivation.

Blue highlight | Location: 3,007 Improvement requires a delicate balance. You need to regularly search for challenges that push you to your edge while continuing to make enough progress to stay motivated. Behaviors need to remain novel in order for them to stay attractive and satisfying. Without variety, we get bored. And boredom is perhaps the greatest villain on the quest for self-improvement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,015 He mentioned the factors you might expect: genetics, luck, talent. But then he said something I wasn‚Äôt expecting: ‚ÄúAt some point it comes down to who can handle the boredom of training every day, doing the same lifts over and over and over.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,017 His answer surprised me because it‚Äôs a different way of thinking about work ethic. People talk about getting ‚Äúamped up‚Äù to work on their goals. Whether it‚Äôs business or sports or art, you hear people say things like, ‚ÄúIt all comes down to passion.‚Äù Or, ‚ÄúYou have to really want it.‚Äù As a result, many of us get depressed when we lose focus or motivation because we think that successful people have some bottomless reserve of passion. But this coach was saying that

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,020 really successful people feel the same lack of motivation as everyone else. The difference is that they still find a way to show up despite the feelings of boredom.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,025 The greatest threat to success is not failure but boredom. We get bored with habits because they stop delighting us.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,029 As Machiavelli noted, ‚ÄúMen desire novelty to such an extent that those who are doing well wish for a change as much as those who are doing badly.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,033 In psychology, this is known as a variable reward.7 fn2 Slot machines are the most common real-world example. A gambler hits the jackpot every now and then but not at any predictable interval. The pace of rewards varies. This variance leads to the greatest

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,036 spike of dopamine, enhances memory recall, and accelerates habit formation.

Blue highlight | Location: 3,037 Variable rewards won‚Äôt create a craving‚Äîthat is, you can‚Äôt take a reward people are uninterested in, give it to them at a variable interval, and hope it will change their mind‚Äîbut they are a powerful way to amplify the cravings we already experience because they reduce boredom.

Blue highlight | Location: 3,043 Of course, not all habits have a variable reward component, and you wouldn‚Äôt want them to. If Google only delivered a useful search result some of the time, I would switch to a competitor pretty quickly. If Uber only picked up half of my trips, I doubt I‚Äôd be using that service much longer.

Blue highlight | Location: 3,050 I can guarantee that if you manage to start a habit and keep sticking to it, there will be days when you feel like quitting. When you start a business, there will be days when you don‚Äôt feel like showing up. When you‚Äôre at the gym, there will be sets that you don‚Äôt feel like finishing. When it‚Äôs time to write, there will be days that you don‚Äôt feel like typing. But stepping up when it‚Äôs annoying or painful or draining to do so, that‚Äôs what makes the difference between a professional and an amateur.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,054 Professionals stick to the schedule; amateurs let life get in the way.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,056 David Cain, an author and meditation teacher, encourages his students to avoid being ‚Äúfair-weather meditators.‚Äù Similarly, you don‚Äôt want to be a fair-weather athlete or a fair-weather writer or a fair-weather anything.

Blue highlight | Location: 3,057 When a habit is truly important to you, you have to be willing to stick to it in any mood.

Pink highlight | Location: 3,058 Professionals take action even when the mood isn‚Äôt right.

Pink highlight | Location: 3,060 There have been a lot of articles I haven‚Äôt felt like writing, but I‚Äôve never regretted publishing on schedule. There have been a lot of days I‚Äôve felt like relaxing, but I‚Äôve never regretted showing up and working on something that was important to me. The only way to become excellent is to be endlessly fascinated by doing the same thing over and over. You have to fall in love with boredom.

Pink highlight | Location: 3,065 The Goldilocks Rule states that humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are right on the edge of their current abilities. ‚ñ† The greatest threat to success is not failure but boredom. ‚ñ† As habits become routine, they become less interesting and less satisfying. We get bored. ‚ñ† Anyone can work hard when they feel motivated. It‚Äôs the ability to keep going when work isn‚Äôt exciting that makes the difference.

Pink highlight | Location: 3,071 Professionals stick to the schedule; amateurs let life get in the way.

When you are 80 years old and in a quiet moment of reflection, narrating for only yourself the most personal version of your life‚Äôs story, the telling that will be most compact and meaningful will be the series of choices you have made.
