Pink highlight | Location: 806 and so conceives of an object of desire,

Pink highlight | Location: 806 This could be something physical like a hike in pay, a product innovation, or the right person

Pink highlight | Location: 809 Nonetheless, all stories dramatize the essential human struggle to move life from chaos to order, from imbalance to equilibrium.

Yellow highlight | Location: 810 We measure the worth of the object of desire in terms of risk: the greater the risk, the greater the object‚Äôs worth. What would you risk your time for? What would you risk your life for? What would you risk your soul for? The most compelling objects of desire come with the highest price tags, and the greater the object‚Äôs worth, the greater the involvement. Contrariwise, watching a character pursue something of no real value is the definition of boredom.

Yellow highlight | Location: 815 storytelling becomes the art of merging and organizing many streams of want into a flow of events that aims at a single object of desire.

Yellow highlight | Location: 823 These desires not only cement the status quo of a character‚Äôs life but also temper his behavior. Background desires form the web of restraints that follow every character into every scene. These fixed desires for stability limit the character‚Äôs actions, restraining what he may or may not say or do to get what he wants.

Yellow highlight | Location: 826 Desire answers what questions: What does the character consciously want? What does he subconsciously long for? Motivation answers why questions. Why does a character want what he wants? Why does he want his particular object of desire?

Pink highlight | Location: 828 The roots of human motivation reach deep into childhood and, for that reason, are often irrational.

Pink highlight | Location: 830 Biographers of historical figures‚ÄîCharles Darwin, Eleanor Roosevelt, Picasso‚Äîdevote chapter upon chapter detailing the upbringing of each, trying to

Pink highlight | Location: 831 document the precise childhood experiences that motivated these personages to do the great things they did.

Orange highlight | Location: 832 Shakespeare, on the other hand, never mentions motivation.

Blue highlight | Location: 834 STAGE FIVE: THE FIRST ACTION PRIME PRINCIPLE: TACTICAL CHOICE

Blue highlight | Location: 835 Desire demands deeds.

Yellow highlight | Location: 836 This positive/negative dynamic propels his story to climax.

Yellow highlight | Location: 838 Every human being acts from one moment to the next on his personal sense of probability, on what he feels will probably happen when he does what he intends to do next.

Yellow highlight | Location: 843 From his quiver of personal tactics, he draws strategic behaviors, all in an effort to move toward his desire of the moment and long-term hopes.

Yellow highlight | Location: 844 And because, like everyone else, he is one of a kind, his sense of what will probably happen when he takes an action will also be one of a kind; therefore, his choice of tactic (exact words, gestures, facial expressions, and so on) will, in turn, be one of a kind.

Yellow highlight | Location: 847 It‚Äôs this infinitude of idiosyncratic tactics that inspires storytellers to imagine unique characters, the sort found in the best-told stories, with behaviors like no one else‚Äôs, behaviors that fascinate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 849 Evolution programmed the genes of every living thing to conserve life down to the last calorie of energy, take no uncalled-for risks, and yet pursue all necessary desires. Therefore, human nature, as a part of Mother Nature, always takes the conservative, minimal, and yet sufficient action in an effort to get what it wants.

Blue highlight | Location: 853 A character will never do less than she has to, nor will she ever do more than she needs to; instead, she will take the minimal, conservative, yet sufficient action that she believes will move her closer to a balanced life.

Blue highlight | Location: 856 Ninety-nine percent of our actions cause the responses we more or less expect.

Blue highlight | Location: 859 To create a meaningful emotional experience for his audience, the storyteller evicts all empty moments, all trivialities and banalities, and embraces those events, and only those events, that bring value-charged change.

Blue highlight | Location: 860 To create value-charged change, the storyteller pits the core character‚Äôs sense of probability against reality‚Äôs forces of necessity.

Blue highlight | Location: 867 When a character‚Äôs world suddenly reacts differently and/or more powerfully than he imagined, this violation of expectation delivers a jolt of surprise, followed by a rush of insight. The clash between what he thinks will happen and the result he actually gets jolts him and splits open his reality.

Blue highlight | Location: 869 The character stares, as it were, into the gap between his subjective anticipation and its objective result. Then with a rush of insight, he suddenly glimpses how his world actually works; how its unforeseen forces of antagonism now block his path.

Blue highlight | Location: 873 When an unanticipated, even contradictory, obstacle violates a protagonist‚Äôs expectations, it moves him farther from his object of desire than he was before he acted.

Blue highlight | Location: 887 Inner Obstacles: Contradictory forces within a character‚Äôs body, emotions, and mind with its warring conscious and subconscious desires.

Blue highlight | Location: 891 To turn a scene means to change its value charge; the phrase turning point names the precise moment when an unforeseen force of antagonism violates expectations and pivots the value at stake from positive to negative or negative to positive.

Blue highlight | Location: 893 Turning points trigger change in only one of two ways‚Äîeither by a direct action followed by the reaction it sparks, or by a revelation of a secret or previously unknown fact and the response it unleashes.

Yellow highlight | Location: 898 The Rational Effects of TURNING POINTS A violation of expectation is, in essence, an effect with an unknown cause. As a result, turning points pop questions into the mind such as ‚ÄúWhy have things taken this unforeseen turn? Why didn‚Äôt the character see this coming? Why didn‚Äôt I? What caused this startling twist?‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 901 A turning point punches a hole in reality. Curiosity

Yellow highlight | Location: 901 compels the audience members to fill the hole with knowledge, so their thoughts rush back through previous scenes and images, looking for an unseen cause, trying to solve the mystery of ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù The answer has been planted beneath the story‚Äôs setups. The moment the audience glimpses this hidden truth, it erupts with an ‚ÄúOh, yeah, now I get it!‚Äù insight that both delights and enlightens.

Yellow highlight | Location: 911 As Aristotle observed, the deepest audience pleasure is learning without being taught. When a tale dramatizes its meaning skillfully, the audience feels no mental strain and yet comes away with a fuller understanding of the workings of the world and the human heart.

Yellow highlight | Location: 916 the like. The mind‚Äôs ranking process keys on the potential for change. So long as life‚Äôs conditions run in neutral, the mind pays no attention and goes about its many tasks. But when things change, awareness snaps to alert as our animal instincts warn us that change threatens survival.

Yellow highlight | Location: 922 Emotion, therefore, is the side effect of change. When the mind senses change from negative to positive, it releases pleasure-giving chemicals; if the mind registers a movement from positive to negative, it unleashes a painful flow.

Yellow highlight | Location: 926 Ad Age named ‚ÄúReal Beauty‚Äù one of the top five ad campaigns of the century.

Yellow highlight | Location: 928 In 2013, Hugo Veiga created a video titled Dove Real Beauty Sketches.2 The story follows a group of women who volunteer for an odd experiment: They agree to have their portrait done by a sketch artist who cannot see them. Instead they will simply tell him what they look like. This act of courage immediately draws empathy from the audience.

Yellow highlight | Location: 936 The above graphic tracks the emotional dynamics in the Dove Real Beauty Sketches video. Its turning points swivel between the opposing poles of its core value, from self-criticism to self-appreciation.

Blue highlight | Location: 946 The story climaxes on the doubly positive charge of self-appreciation. During this decisive transition, the audience shares in the women‚Äôs triumph over self-criticism and feels, with them, a positive emotion.

Blue highlight | Location: 948 All well-told stories express how and why life changes, and, as we noted above,

Orange highlight | Location: 948 the side effect of change is emotion.

Blue highlight | Location: 949 These feelings, however, only come to life during a transition. As a story shifts from positive to negative, the audience feels a dark emotion; as it transitions from negative to positive, a light emotion fills them. Once change completes itself, however, emotion quickly dissipates, ready to move in a new direction. To grip and hold emotional involvement, a story‚Äôs values must transition dynamically from change to change to change.

Blue highlight | Location: 957 Faced with an array of possible actions, she must choose one last tactic in a final effort to put life back in balance.

Blue highlight | Location: 958 Decisions come in two kinds: clear choices versus dilemmas‚Äîthe easy versus the hard.

Blue highlight | Location: 960 Clear choices obey nature‚Äôs grand imperative: Always choose the positive.

Blue highlight | Location: 961 Every living thing, flora and fauna, instinctively heeds the two laws governing the conservation of energy and life: (1) Never do anything you don‚Äôt have to do if you can get what you want the easier way. (2) Never take any risk you don‚Äôt have to take if you can get what you want the safer way.

Blue highlight | Location: 968 Dilemmas also come in two kinds, and both are hard because they pose a choice between either two positives or two negatives, known respectively as irreconcilable goods and the lesser of two evils.

Blue highlight | Location: 972 The hard choice of dilemma causes anxiety before the choice and risk during it.

Blue highlight | Location: 975 But as we‚Äôll see in the next chapter, in the marketer‚Äôs purpose-told story, the protagonist‚Äôs climactic choice must be pressure-and stress-free.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,013 Unlike full-length fictions, purpose-told stories abbreviate events. The typical business story is a mini-tale told in a thirty-second commercial or a three-minute YouTube video. GE‚Äôs ‚ÄúOwen‚Äù ads and the Dove Real Beauty Sketches are two perfect examples of each.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,016 The marketing story, no. Purpose-told works crack open the gap between expectation and result usually only once, perhaps twice, maybe three times at the most.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,028 The purpose-told‚Äôs audience members take their storified experience into the real world and relive it each and every time they purchase the subject product or service. In other words, the purpose of the purpose-told story is to transform the aesthetic pleasure of a story‚Äôs climax into a viable action in the marketplace‚Äîto turn audiences into consumers.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,032 we gain an insight into life we never knew before, all enveloped in emotions we never felt quite that way before. This fusion of idea and emotion adds a measure of enrichment, great or small, to our inner life. We exit a beautifully told story a fuller human being than when we entered.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,035 The fiction-told story fulfills itself in one telling, whereas the purpose-told story retells its tale in the mind of the consumer each and every time she buys its product or hires its service.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,038 Concentrated experiences entertain because they carry us through time unaware of the passage of time.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,047 The audience of the purpose-told story, on the other hand, ignores the artist and feels brand loyalty instead. THE MIRROR EXPERIENCE Well-told stories create two simultaneous experiences that mirror each other: one mental, the other emotional. The mental mirror experience begins and ends with curiosity. A story‚Äôs inciting incident teases the audience‚Äôs mind with unanswered questions such as ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going to happen next? What‚Äôll happen after that? How will this story turn out? Will the protagonist win his object of desire?‚Äù The rational mirror experience in story mirrors the same set

The moment the target consumer recognizes a shared humanity between herself and the protagonist, her instincts follow the logic of kinship: ‚ÄúThat character is a human being like me. Therefore, I want that character to get what he wants, because if I were that character in that situation, I would want the same thing for myself.‚Äù In other words, she bonds.2

Blue highlight | Location: 1,065 She instinctively experiences the events as if they were happening to her.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,067 Third, the reenactment. The consumer‚Äôs mirror experience motivates her to act. Wishing to relive the positive charge of the purpose-told story, she purchases the product or hires the service embedded in the telling. Her post-story reenactment satisfies her need and the marketer‚Äôs purpose simultaneously. In short, she becomes a customer.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,424 Today the CMO occupies a new, critical, and far broader role in the company than ever before: change agent. THE CMO AS CHANGE AGENT

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,428 Your first task as change agent is to educate your executive team on the worldwide shift from ad-centric to story-centric marketing. No small task. Conventional C-suite wisdom holds that six-year-olds crave stories, while hard-charging executives don‚Äôt. But you know that if your company doesn‚Äôt change its MO, it won‚Äôt survive, so you must build a winning case to convince the C-suite.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,434 Once your executives are on board with the concept, teach the eight stages of story creation to sales, marketing, product development, communications, investor relations, and leadership at all corporate levels. Finally, to put storytelling into practice, coach your team to change their thinking habits in six decisive ways:

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,437 Change your team‚Äôs analytical method from deductive logic to causal logic.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,445 Change the team‚Äôs sales practices from additive to progressive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,453 Change the team‚Äôs worldview from narrow and shallow to wide and deep.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,457 Dove‚Äôs ‚ÄúReal Beauty‚Äù stories drive their campaign by foregrounding the inner conflict of self-criticism versus self-appreciation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,460 story. Train your teams to work through all levels of antagonism so they can craft stories that resonate with the consumer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,462 Change your team‚Äôs understanding of values. Convincing storytelling depends on an authenticity of values. Therefore, a transformational

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,468 Change your team‚Äôs marketing theory to embrace emotional intelligence.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,470 The key to decision making is emotion, and emotion is not information. The emotionally targeted question you should ask is: ‚ÄúHow do I want my customers to feel?‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,472 Your team members must frame their stories to create a feeling of fusion between protagonist and audience. When empathy seals the deal, use progressive conflict and value charge changes to hook and hold your audience, and finally reward it with a story climax that reinforces brand or product values.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,474 Change the team‚Äôs mental model from static description to dynamic storytelling.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,481 As corporate showrunner, the modern CMO educates her team in story craft, produces a storytelling strategy for the brand, and operationalizes its storytelling processes.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,482 She recruits the right creatives, guides moment-by-moment storytelling to ensure brand/voice alignment, and exercises good taste to guarantee a quality experience for the brand‚Äôs prospective customers. It‚Äôs a big job.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,487 Every CMO starts his day staring at this hard truth: Nobody wants to hear about your company or your product.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,491 Typically, consumers only debate brands in the mental minute just before they make a purchase. That precious minute makes storified branding an imperative for modern marketing.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,500 Brand is a single organizing idea, a higher-order construct that everything else comes from and aligns with. Sometimes I liken it to the fresh water that makes everything else possible, whether that is growing your crops or cleaning your clothes or making soup. It‚Äôs that ingredient that goes across everything else.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,503 Finding a fresh source of water that won‚Äôt be depleted and can be used in hundreds and hundreds of ways is a challenge. Which is to say [brand] is intangible, it is abstract, and it is true. It has to be all of those things at

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,505 The job of the marketer is to make it tangible and real and to work with its truth to tell a story that is compelling whether it happens in one image or three lines or a long-form piece.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,506 All of that is in service of saying we want brands to be a link between a number of positive associations for the consumer, and increasingly for communities and constituencies beyond the consumer, to say that we can all come together around this one big higher-order idea.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,508 It is a belief system, and like any belief system, it has its language, it has symbols, it has rituals, and behaviors to go with them.1

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,512 Those brands are all owned by the same company, and in fact, consumers may choose those brands at different points in their weekend, because they are conveying different aspects of their personality with that badge, with the beer bottle they are holding.‚Äù The brands we choose reflect how we see ourselves or, perhaps, how we want the world to see us.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,514 Originally, Davis pointed out, brands were simply a means of identifying the producer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,515 The purpose of the brand was to show that a certain person had made that specific piece. Whether silver goods or porcelain or leather goods, wares were hallmarked by their maker (in effect, they were branded like cattle).

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,518 ‚ÄúThe mark is just a shortcut, a signal for [the brand]. [The brand] still exists and survives beyond the product and beyond the mark and that‚Äôs when you get into some very interesting work.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,519 How can you create a brand that matters so much to people that they make it part of their self-expression? For generations, television advertising did the trick. Not anymore. To connect with audiences today, we need a different approach. And it had better be good, because we‚Äôve got a steep hill to climb.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,554 The willingness of these companies to put profits above the well-being of their customers, their neighbors, and the environment has not just damaged their individual reputations. It has damaged the perception of businesses in general.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,557 What‚Äôs more, they believe the problem begins at the top: Just 37 percent of those surveyed find CEOs to be credible.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,561 Sick of being fooled, people assume that the phrase for profit means ‚Äúat any cost,‚Äù even the possibility of harm to the consumer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,562 Overcoming skepticism is like overcoming gravity. It‚Äôs a natural force, buttressed by the endless bragging and over-promising of brands.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,564 The well-told story erases skepticism by wrapping the story‚Äôs meaning inside an emotion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,565 The source of this psychological power is empathic identification.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,565 Once an audience instinctively links its sense of self with a protagonist, doubt vanishes. The protagonist‚Äôs choices and actions become the audience‚Äôs vicarious choices and actions.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,568 Like an epiphany, a story‚Äôs climactic action floods the mind with a sense of truth.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,569 Because the audience member‚Äôs own thoughts spontaneously form this idea, she believes in it without rationalization or any hint of skepticism. It‚Äôs hers, after all. What‚Äôs more, the pleasure-filled emotion aroused by this sudden insight engraves the experience into her memory. From that day on, her upbeat remembrance surrounds the brand with a subliminal halo that influences her purchases. This is how stories, consistently told well, establish a meaningful brand in the minds of

Orange highlight | Location: 1,572 consumers.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,573 Once you determine your audience (Stage One of the storytelling process), you must choose subject matter that contains a physical and social setting, a core value, and a protagonist (Stage Two). Subject matter possibilities for brands fall into at least five grand genres: origin, history, mission, product, and customer stories. You need a least one story to define your brand, but some brands tell thousands.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,585 Once again, empathy. Genius-in-a-garage stories are as old as Thomas Edison. They touch the heart because they star the iconic American business hero: a young shoestring entrepreneur battling shortsighted prejudice and overwhelming odds.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,586 If your company has a powerful origin story, and the core value of that story aligns with your brand‚Äôs, make it the first story you tell to establish your brand in the minds of your consumers.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,588 In truth, however, successful businesses rarely begin with action movie heroism. They take root in three things: a good idea, hard work, and persistence.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,591 As we pointed out in chapter 4, stories progress with emotional dynamics; narratives repeat emotionless facts. Consider, for example, the Coca-Cola website piece titled

Orange highlight | Location: 1,593 ‚Äú125 Years of Sharing Happiness.‚Äù13 It makes a grand promise‚Ä¶

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,594 This is the remarkable story about the evolution of an iconic brand and the company that bears its name. These unique moments in history, arranged in chronological sequence, have helped create a global brand that provides billions of moments of refreshment every day.

It‚Äôs not an apple, Patrick Davis pointed out, it‚Äôs an apple with a bite taken out of it. That image retells the foundational story of Judeo-Christian heritage. The first bite from the tree of knowledge celebrates humankind‚Äôs greatest act of rebellion.

Digging deeper, the executives asked, ‚ÄúWhat do our customers want to feel?‚Äù The answer came back: ‚ÄúFrenetic energy.‚Äù This insight led to their discovery of the brand‚Äôs core value: excitement/boredom. The next logical step was to tell online consumer-centric stories that couple powerful writing with original pulse-pounding film to dynamically dramatize the company‚Äôs core value from the consumer‚Äôs point of view.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,651 This is why when you visit Red Bull‚Äôs website, you won‚Äôt find a picture of a Red Bull can or any bragging about its contents. Why? Because Red Bull recognizes that its typical fifteen-to twenty-five-year-old male customer doesn‚Äôt

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,654 The marketers know that if a guy who‚Äôs watched RedBull.tv sees a choice between Red Bull and a competitor, he will recall the edge-of-his-seat emotion their storytelling pocketed in his mind and reach for their brand‚Äî

Orange highlight | Location: 1,673 Havas Media defines meaningful brands as those that inspire the thought, This brand improves my life. This sense of enhancement envelops both the consumer and the brand in an aura of well-being.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,691 Put simply, we want more from life than money. People want genuine human connection, to be treated fairly, and to be treated honestly.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,692 Given this context, to create a meaningful brand in the minds of consumers, it must be authentic. Consumers find a brand trustworthy and meaningful when two stories match: the story the brand tells about itself and the story the public tells about the brand.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,694 all brand stories must follow one simple principle: The core value of the story must match the core value of the brand. If these stories do not align, if promises made are not kept, the public feels betrayed and their sense of injustice indicts the brand as detrimental to their lives.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,703 Havas reports that meaningfulness drives disproportionate financial results. Their global study of a thousand companies, employing three hundred thousand people, in thirty-four countries, across twelve industries, found that fully meaningful brands ‚Äú.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâsee their marketing KPIs perform 100 percent better overall compared with less Meaningful Brands.‚Äù

Orange highlight | Location: 1,706 In fact, every 10 percent improvement in ‚Äúmeaningfulness‚Äù increases purchase intent by 6.6 percent, repurchase intent by 3.2 percent, customer advocacy by 4.8 percent, and premium pricing by 10.4 percent. Meaningful brands gain, on average, 46 percent more share of wallet than those ranked as not meaningful. What‚Äôs more, meaningful brands outperformed the overall stock market by 133 percent.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,709 The facts are clear: Marketers whose brand stories match consumers‚Äô stories see their tales retold as consumer identification drives significantly better returns for team members and shareholders.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,803 Instead online searches drive their active discovery, while social media provides for passive discovery.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,807 Over the same four weeks, thirty billion people with no specific goal follow curiosity where it leads to Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Instagram, Snapchat, or Pinterest, and by pure coincidence learn something interesting, something of value.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,809 These chance revelations often feel like a gift from beyond, so people share their passive discoveries with friends and family, compounding these serendipities from thirty to ninety billion.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,810 These tens of billions of discoveries offer an unprecedented marketing opportunity, if you provide the information or entertainment your customers seek.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,813 This means that like blank billboards along a highway, search and social discoveries offer CMOs new ways to reach customers and build ongoing relationships,

Never underestimate the power of first impressions. When your customer first arrives, consider giving him a gift.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,819 Content marketing creates material your customers want or need, instead of repeating messages describing the features and benefits of your company or products.

Orange highlight | Location: 1,824 Today one of the highest honors awarded any restaurateur is a ‚ÄúMichelin Star.‚Äù Not bad for a tire company.

Now she‚Äôs inside, looking around, and your visitor moves from anonymous consumer to prospect. Let your sales team take her the next step from prospect to customer.

Every month Colgate.com broadens its audience and builds relationships that last. Second, Colgate does not use the Oral Care Center to promote the benefits of Colgate products. Brands lose credibility when they shift the focus of their content from helping the customer back to the bragging and promising of yesteryear.

Blue highlight | Location: 1,881 Companies evolve into content marketing leaders when they move from sustained content creation to sustained storytelling.

So storytelling becomes extraordinarily important.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Location: 1,911 The core value of the story must align with the core value of the brand.

Orange highlight | Page: 10 Twenty-five years of research in seventeen different organizations has taught us that individuals who are the most influential‚Äîwho can get things done and at the same time build on relationships‚Äîare those who master their crucial conversations.

Orange highlight | Page: 10 high performers know how to stand up to the boss without committing career suicide. We‚Äôve all seen people hurt their careers by ineffectively discussing tough issues.

Note:Important issue - career obstacles

Orange highlight | Page: 10 You may have done it yourself. Fed up with a lengthy and unhealthy pattern of behavior, you finally speak out‚Äîbut a bit too abruptly. Oops. Or maybe an issue becomes so hot that as your peers twitch and fidget themselves into a quivering mass of potential stroke victims, you decide to say something. It‚Äôs not a pretty discussion‚Äîbut somebody has to have the guts to keep the boss from doing something stupid. (Gulp.)

Orange highlight | Page: 10 You don‚Äôt have to choose between candor and your career.

Orange highlight | Page: 10 People who routinely hold crucial conversations and hold them well are able to express controversial and even risky opinions in a way that gets heard. Their bosses, peers, and direct reports listen without becoming defensive or angry.

Orange highlight | Page: 10 Are there crucial conversations that you‚Äôre not holding or not holding well? Is

Orange highlight | Page: 10 this undermining your influence? And more importantly, would your career take a step forward if you could improve how you‚Äôre dealing with these conversations?

Blue highlight | Page: 20 One of the opinion leaders we became particularly interested in meeting was named Kevin. He was the only one of eight vice presidents in his company to be identified as exceedingly influential. We wanted to know why. So we watched him at work. At first, Kevin didn‚Äôt do anything remarkable. In truth, he looked like every other VP. He answered his phone, talked to his direct reports, and continued about his pleasant, but routine, routine.

Blue highlight | Page: 20 team. No vague claim went unclarified, no unsupported reasoning unquestioned.

Blue highlight | Page: 21 Kevin continued to explain what he saw happening, and when he finished the first minutes of this delicate exchange, Chris was quiet for a moment. Then he nodded his head. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre absolutely right,‚Äù he finally concluded. ‚ÄúI have been trying to force my opinion on you. Let‚Äôs back up and try again.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 21 ‚ÄúDid you see how he did that? If you want to know how he gets things done, figure out what he just did.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 21 So we did. In fact, we spent the next twenty-five years discovering what Kevin and people like him do. What typically set them apart from the rest of the pack was their ability to avoid what we came to call the Fool‚Äôs Choice.

Blue highlight | Page: 22 The mistake most of us make in our crucial conversations is we believe that we have to choose between telling the truth and keeping a friend.

Blue highlight | Page: 22 Consider Kevin, the all-star. When he took a breath and opened his mouth, his overriding question was, ‚ÄúHow can I be 100 percent honest with Chris, and at the same time be 100 percent respectful?‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 22 They not only refused to make the Fool‚Äôs Choice, but they then acted in ways that were far more skilled than their colleagues.

Blue highlight | Page: 23 When it comes to risky, controversial, and emotional conversations, skilled people find a way to get all relevant information (from themselves and others) out into the open.

Blue highlight | Page: 23 At the core of every successful conversation lies the free flow of relevant information. People openly and honestly express their opinions, share their feelings, and articulate their theories. They willingly and capably share their views, even when their ideas are controversial or unpopular. It‚Äôs the one thing that, and precisely what, Kevin and the other extremely effective communicators we studied were routinely able to achieve. Now, to put a label on this spectacular talent‚Äîit‚Äôs called dialogue.

Blue highlight | Page: 23 di¬∑a¬∑logue or di¬∑a¬∑log (d√¨¬¥ ‚àÇ-l√¥g¬¥¬¥, -l√≤g) n The free flow of meaning between two or more people.

Blue highlight | Page: 24 Each of us enters conversations with our own opinions, feelings, theories, and experiences about the topic at hand. This unique combination of thoughts and feelings makes up our personal pool of meaning. This pool not only informs us, but also propels our every action.

Blue highlight | Page: 24 People who are skilled at dialogue do their best to make it safe for everyone to add their meaning to the shared pool‚Äîeven ideas that at first glance appear controversial, wrong, or at odds with their own beliefs. Now, obviously, they don‚Äôt agree with every idea; they simply do their best to ensure that all ideas find their way into the open.

Blue highlight | Page: 24 As the Pool of Shared Meaning grows, it helps people in two ways. First, as individuals are exposed to more accurate and relevant information, they make better choices.

Blue highlight | Page: 24 In a very real sense, the Pool of Shared Meaning is a measure of

Blue highlight | Page: 24 a group‚Äôs IQ. The larger the shared pool, the smarter the decisions. And even though many people may be involved in a choice, when people openly and freely share ideas, the increased time investment is more than offset by the quality of the decision.

Blue highlight | Page: 24 On the other hand, we‚Äôve all seen what happens when the shared pool is dangerously shallow. When people purposefully withhold meaning from one another, individually smart people can do collectively stupid things.

On the other hand, when people feel comfortable speaking up and meaning does flow freely, the shared pool can dramatically increase a group‚Äôs ability

Blue highlight | Page: 25 to make better decisions. Consider what happened to Kevin‚Äôs group. As everyone on the team began to explain his or her opinion, people formed a clearer and more complete picture of the circumstances.

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 To help catch problems early, reprogram your mind to

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 pay attention to the signs that suggest you‚Äôre in a crucial conversation. Some people first notice physical signals‚Äîtheir stomach gets tight or their eyes get dry. Think about what happens to your body when conversations get tough. Everyone is a little bit different. What are your cues? Whatever they are, learn to look at them as signs to step back, slow down, and Start with Heart before things get out of hand.

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 People who are

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 gifted at dialogue keep a constant vigil on safety. They pay

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 When it‚Äôs safe, you can say anything. Here‚Äôs why gifted communicators keep a close eye on safety. Dialogue calls for the free flow of meaning‚Äîperiod. And nothing kills the flow of meaning like fear.

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 This is a pretty remarkable claim. Think about it. We‚Äôre suggesting that people rarely become defensive simply because of what you‚Äôre saying. They only become defensive when they no longer feel safe. The problem is not the content of your message, but the condition of the conversation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 56 On the other hand, if you don‚Äôt feel safe, you can‚Äôt take any feedback.

Yellow highlight | Page: 56 It‚Äôs as if the pool of meaning has a lid on it. ‚ÄúWhat do you mean I look good? Is that some kind of joke? Are you insulting me?‚Äù When you don‚Äôt feel safe, even well-intended comments are suspect.

Yellow highlight | Page: 56 When it‚Äôs unsafe, you start to go blind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 As we‚Äôve said before, when your emotions start cranking up, key brain functions start shutting down. Not only do you prepare to take flight, but your peripheral vision actually narrows. In fact, when you feel genuinely threatened, you can scarcely see beyond what‚Äôs right in front of you.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 By pulling yourself out of the content of an argument and looking for signs that safety is a risk, you reengage your brain and your full vision returns.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 As we suggested earlier, when you give your brain a new problem to consider (keep alert for signs that safety is at risk!), it affects your brain functioning. Your higher reasoning centers stay more active, and you‚Äôre far less likely to be dumbed down and far more likely to succeed in your crucial conversation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 Don‚Äôt let safety problems lead you astray.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 Imagine the magnitude of what we‚Äôre suggesting here. We‚Äôre asking you to recode silence and violence as signs that people are feeling unsafe.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 We‚Äôre asking you to fight your natural tendency to respond in kind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 We‚Äôre asking you to undo years of practice, maybe even eons of genetic shaping that prod you to take flight or pick a fight (when under attack), and recode the stimulus. ‚ÄúAh, that‚Äôs a sign that the other person feels unsafe.‚Äù And then what? Do something to make it safe.

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 Imagine increased influence, enhanced relationships, stronger teams, and more effective leadership. Turn on your capacity to recognize and respond to safety problems.

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 In the next chapter we‚Äôll explore how. For now, simply learn to look for safety, and then be curious, not angry or frightened.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 Do others believe I care about their goals in this conversation? ‚Ä¢ Do they trust my motives?

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 What do I want for me? ‚Ä¢ What do I want for others? ‚Ä¢ What do I want for the relationship?

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 Look for the mutuality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve got a boss who frequently fails to keep commitments. How could you tell the boss you don‚Äôt trust him? Surely there‚Äôs no way to say this without the boss becoming defensive or vengeful, because he knows that your goal is merely to make your life better. To avoid disaster, find a Mutual Purpose that would be so motivating to the boss that he‚Äôd want to hear your concerns. If your only reason for approaching the boss is to get

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 what you want, the boss will hear you as critical and selfish‚Äî

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 which is what you are.

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 Imagine raising the topic this way: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got some ideas for how I can be much more reliable and even reduce costs by a few thousand dollars in preparing the report each month. It‚Äôs going to be a bit of a sensitive conversation‚Äîbut I think it will help a great deal if we can talk about it.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 While it‚Äôs true that there‚Äôs no reason to enter a crucial conversation if you don‚Äôt have Mutual Purpose, it‚Äôs equally true that you can‚Äôt stay in the conversation if you don‚Äôt maintain Mutual Respect. Mutual Respect is the continuance condition of dialogue. As people perceive that others don‚Äôt respect them, the conversation immediately becomes unsafe and dialogue comes to a screeching halt.

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 Why? Because respect is like air. As long as it‚Äôs present, nobody thinks about it. But if you take it away, it‚Äôs all that people can think about. The instant people perceive disrespect in a conversation, the interaction is no longer about the original purpose‚Äîit is now about defending dignity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 Telltale signs. To spot when respect is violated and safety takes a turn south, watch for signs that people are defending their dignity.

Blue highlight | Page: 79 Emotions

Blue highlight | Page: 79 When people feel disrespected, they become highly charged. Their emotions turn from fear to anger. Then they resort to pouting, name-calling, yelling, and making threats. Ask the following question to determine when Mutual Respect is at risk:

Yellow highlight | Page: 80 Do others believe I respect them?

Blue highlight | Page: 80 How, they wonder, can they share the same purpose with people who come from completely different backgrounds or whose morals or values differ from theirs? What do you do, for example, if you‚Äôre upset because another person has let you down? And if this has repeatedly happened, how can you respect a person who is so poorly motivated and selfish?

Blue highlight | Page: 80 Dialogue truly would be doomed if we had to share every objective or respect every element of another person‚Äôs character before we could talk.

Blue highlight | Page: 80 However, we can stay in dialogue by finding a way to honor and regard another person‚Äôs basic humanity.

Blue highlight | Page: 80 In essence, feelings of disrespect often come when we dwell on how others are different from ourselves.

Note:Difference - disrespect

Blue highlight | Page: 80 We can counteract these feelings by looking for ways we are similar. Without excusing others‚Äô behavior, we try to sympathize, even empathize, with them.

Blue highlight | Page: 80 prayer‚Äî‚ÄúLord, help me forgive those who sin differently than I.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 80 When we do this, we feel a kinship or mutuality between ourselves and even the thorniest of people.

Blue highlight | Page: 80 This sense of kinship and connection to others helps create Mutual Respect and eventually enables us to stay in dialogue with virtually anyone.

Blue highlight | Page: 81 Each group was to go into a separate room and write out its goals for the company on flip-chart-sized paper.

Blue highlight | Page: 81 After a few minutes the two groups returned to the training room. They were positively stunned. It was as if they had written the exact same lists. They didn‚Äôt merely share the shadow of an idea or two. Their aspirations were nearly identical. All wanted a profitable company, stable and rewarding jobs, high-quality products, and a positive impact on the community. Given a chance to speak freely and without fear of attack, each group laid out not simply what it wanted, but what virtually every person wanted.

Blue highlight | Page: 82 Apologize ‚Ä¢ Contrast ‚Ä¢ Create a Mutual Purpose

Blue highlight | Page: 83 But you fail to restore safety. Why? Because now you feel disrespected. They‚Äôve attacked you. So you stay stuck in the content of the conversation‚Äîthinking this has something to do with the factory tour.

Blue highlight | Page: 83 See their aggressive behavior for what it is‚Äîa sign of violated safety‚Äî

Blue highlight | Page: 84 When you‚Äôve made a mistake that has hurt others (e.g., you didn‚Äôt call the team), start with an apology. An apology is a statement that sincerely expresses your sorrow for your role in causing‚Äîor at least not preventing‚Äîpain or difficulty to others.

Blue highlight | Page: 84 Now, an apology isn‚Äôt really an apology unless you experience a change in heart. To offer a sincere apology, your motives have to change. You have to give up saving face, being right, or winning in order to focus on what you really want. You have to sacrifice a bit of your ego by admitting your error. But like many sacrifices, when you give up something you value, you‚Äôre rewarded with something even more valuable‚Äîhealthy dialogue and better results.

Blue highlight | Page: 84 Sometimes others feel disrespected during crucial conversations even though you haven‚Äôt done anything disrespectful.

Blue highlight | Page: 84 But just as often, the insult is entirely unintended.

Blue highlight | Page: 85 When others misinterpret either your purpose or your intent, step out of the argument and rebuild safety by using a skill called Contrasting.

Blue highlight | Page: 85 Contrasting is a don‚Äôt/do statement that:

Blue highlight | Page: 85 Addresses others‚Äô concerns that you don‚Äôt respect them or that you have a malicious purpose (the don‚Äôt part). ‚Ä¢ Confirms your respect or clarifies your real purpose (the do part).

Blue highlight | Page: 85 [The don‚Äôt part] ‚ÄúThe last thing I wanted to do was communicate that I don‚Äôt value the work you put in or that I didn‚Äôt want to share it with the VP. [The do part] I think your work has been nothing short of spectacular.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 86 Of the two parts of Contrasting, the don‚Äôt is the more important because it deals with the misunderstanding that has put safety at risk.

Blue highlight | Page: 87 Contrasting provides context and proportion.

Blue highlight | Page: 87 you talk with your assistant about his lack

Blue highlight | Page: 88 At this point, you could be tempted to water down your content‚Äî‚ÄúYou know it‚Äôs really not that big a deal.‚Äù Don‚Äôt give into the temptation. Don‚Äôt take back what you‚Äôve said. Instead, put your remarks in context.

Blue highlight | Page: 88 ‚ÄúLet me put this in perspective. I don‚Äôt want you to think I‚Äôm not satisfied with the quality of your work. I want us to continue working together. I really do think you‚Äôre doing a good job. This punctuality issue is important to me, and I‚Äôd just like you to work on that. If you will be more attentive to that, there are no other issues.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 88 Use Contrasting for prevention or first aid. Contrasting can be useful both as prevention and as first aid for safety problems.

Blue highlight | Page: 88 So far our examples have helped us apply first

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 aid to a wounded conversation. Someone has taken something wrong, and we‚Äôve intervened to clarify our true purpose or meaning. When we‚Äôre aware that something we‚Äôre about to drop into the pool of meaning

Blue highlight | Page: 88 When people misunderstand and you start arguing over the misunderstanding, stop. Use Contrasting. Explain what you don‚Äôt mean until you‚Äôve restored safety. Then return to the conversation. Safety first.

Blue highlight | Page: 91 The worst at dialogue either ignore the problem and push ahead or roll over and let others have their way. They opt for either competition or submission. Both strategies end up making winners and losers, and the problem continues long beyond the initial conversation.

Blue highlight | Page: 91 The good at dialogue move immediately toward compromise. For example, the couple facing the transfer sets up two house-holds‚Äîone where the transferred spouse will be working and one where the family currently lives. Nobody really wants this arrangement, and frankly, it‚Äôs a pretty ugly solution that‚Äôs bound to lead to more serious problems, even divorce. While compromise is sometimes necessary,

Blue highlight | Page: 91 The best at dialogue use four skills to create a Mutual Purpose. If it helps you remember what to do, note that the four skills used in creating Mutual Purpose form the acronym CRIB.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 You make you mad. You make you scared, annoyed, or insulted. You and only you create your emotions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 Claim two. Once you‚Äôve created your upset emotions, you have only two options: You can act on them or be acted on by them. That is, when it comes to strong emotions, you either find a way to master them or fall hostage to them. Here‚Äôs how this all unfolds.

Yellow highlight | Page: 106 The best at dialogue do something completely different. They aren‚Äôt held hostage by their emotions, nor do they try to hide or suppress them. Instead, they act on their emotions. That is, when they have strong

Yellow highlight | Page: 107 feelings, they influence (and often change) their emotions by thinking them out. As a result, they choose their emotions, and by so doing, make it possible to choose behaviors that create better results.

Yellow highlight | Page: 107 holding her feelings inside (avoiding) and taking cheap shots (masking).

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 As it turns out, there is an intermediate step between what others do and how we feel.

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 There‚Äôs always an intermediate step because actions themselves can‚Äôt and don‚Äôt cause emotional reactions. That‚Äôs why, when faced with the exact same circumstances, ten people may have ten different emotional responses. For instance, with a coworker like Louis, some might feel insulted whereas others merely feel curious. Some become angry and others feel concern or even sympathy.

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 What is this intermediate step? Just after we observe what others do and just before we feel some emotion about it, we tell ourselves a story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 We add meaning to the action we observed. We make a guess at the motive driving the behavior.

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 Why were they doing that? We also add judgment‚Äîis that good or bad? And then, based on these thoughts or stories, our body responds with

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 an emotion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 109 Stories provide our rationale for

Yellow highlight | Page: 109 what‚Äôs going on. They‚Äôre our interpretations of the facts. They help explain what we see and hear. They‚Äôre theories we use to explain why, how, and what. For instance, Maria asks: ‚ÄúWhy does Louis take over? He doesn‚Äôt trust my ability to communicate. He thinks that because I‚Äôm a woman, people won‚Äôt listen to me.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 If we take control of our stories, they won‚Äôt control us. People who excel at dialogue are able to influence their emotions during crucial conversations. They recognize that while it‚Äôs true that at first we are in control of the stories we tell‚Äîafter all, we do make them up of our own accord‚Äîonce they‚Äôre told, the stories control us.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 But it doesn‚Äôt have to be this way. We can tell different stories and break the loop. In fact, until we tell different stories, we cannot break the loop.

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 Not only do those who are best at crucial conversations notice when they‚Äôre slipping into silence or violence, but they‚Äôre also able to admit it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 The moment they realize that they‚Äôre killing dialogue, they review their own Path to Action.

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 Actually, identifying your emotions is more difficult than you might imagine. In fact, many people are emotionally illiterate. When asked to describe how they‚Äôre feeling, they use words such as ‚Äúbad‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 or ‚Äúangry‚Äù or ‚Äúfrightened‚Äù‚Äîwhich would be okay if these were accurate descriptors, but often they‚Äôre not.

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 Individuals say they‚Äôre angry when, in fact, they‚Äôre feeling a mix of embarrassment and surprise. Or they suggest they‚Äôre unhappy when they‚Äôre feeling violated. Perhaps they suggest they‚Äôre upset when

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 they‚Äôre really feeling humiliated and cheated.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 Since life doesn‚Äôt consist of a series of vocabulary tests, you might wonder what difference words can make. But words do matter. Knowing what you‚Äôre really feeling helps you take a more accurate look at what is going on and why. For instance, you‚Äôre far

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 more likely to take an honest look at the story you‚Äôre telling yourself if you admit you‚Äôre feeling both embarrassed and surprised rather than simply angry.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 Meaning, of course, are you telling the right story? After all, feelings come from stories, and stories are our own invention.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 The first step to regaining emotional control is to challenge the illusion that what you‚Äôre feeling is the only right emotion under the circumstances.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 This may be the hardest step, but it‚Äôs also the most important one.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 By questioning our feelings, we open ourselves up to question our stories. We challenge the comfortable conclusion that our story is right and true. We willingly question whether our emotions (very real), and the story behind them (only one of many possible explanations), are accurate.

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 As we said earlier, others could watch Maria‚Äôs interactions with Louis and walk away with different stories.

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 Test your ideas against a simple criterion: Can you see or hear this thing you‚Äôre calling a fact? Was it an actual behavior?

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 However, the statement ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt trust me‚Äù is a conclusion. It explains what you think, not what the other person did. Conclusions are subjective.

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 Either our stories are completely accurate and propel us in healthy directions, or they‚Äôre quite inaccurate but justify our current behavior

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 us feel good about ourselves and calling for no need to change.

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 We call these imaginative and self-serving concoctions ‚Äúclever stories.‚Äù They‚Äôre clever because they allow us to feel good about behaving badly. Better yet, they allow us to feel good about behaving badly even while achieving abysmal results. When we feel a need to justify

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 we tend to tell our stories in three very predictable ways. Learn what the three are and how to counteract them, and you can take control of your emotional

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 In Victim Stories we exaggerate our own innocence. In Villain Stories we overemphasize the other person‚Äôs guilt or stupidity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 We automatically assume the worst possible motives or grossest incompetence while ignoring any possible good or neutral

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 intentions or skills a person may have.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 Labeling is a common device in Villain Stories. For example, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe that bonehead gave me bad materials again.‚Äù By employing the handy label, we are now dealing not with a complex human being, but with a bonehead.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 After all, we can feel okay insulting or abusing a bonehead‚Äîwhereas we might have to be more careful with a living, breathing person.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 Then when we fail to get the results we really want, we stay stuck in our ineffective behavior because, after all, look who we‚Äôre dealing with!

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 Finally come Helpless Stories. In

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 these fabrications we make ourselves out to be powerless to do anything healthy or helpful.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 We convince ourselves that there are no healthy alternatives for dealing with our predicament, which justifies the action we‚Äôre about to take.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 Villain and Victim Stories look back to explain why we‚Äôre in the situation we‚Äôre in, Helpless Stories look forward to explain why we can‚Äôt do anything to change our situation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 helpless when we turn others‚Äô behavior into fixed and unchangeable traits. For example, when we decide our colleague is a ‚Äúcontrol freak‚Äù (Villain Story), we are less inclined to give her feedback because, after all, control freaks like her don‚Äôt accept feedback (Helpless Story). Nothing we can do will change that fact.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 As you can see, Helpless Stories often stem from Villain Stories and typically offer us nothing more than Fool‚Äôs Choices‚Äî we can either be honest and ruin the relationship or stay silent and suffer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 Clever stories match reality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 120 Clever stories get us off the hook.

Yellow highlight | Page: 121 Your spouse‚Äôs annoying habit didn‚Äôt become a source of resentment until you became part of the problem.

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 Once we‚Äôve learned to recognize the clever stories we tell ourselves, we can move to the final Master My Stories skill. The dialogue-smart

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 recognize that they‚Äôre telling clever stories, stop, and then do what it takes to tell a useful story. A useful story, by definition, creates emotions that lead to healthy action‚Äîsuch as dialogue.

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 ‚Ä¢ Am I pretending not to notice my role in the problem? This question jars you into facing up to the fact that maybe, just maybe, you did something to help cause the problem.

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 Perhaps your contribution was merely a thoughtless omission. Nonetheless, you contributed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 Turn villains into humans. When you find yourself labeling or otherwise vilifying others, stop and ask:

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 ‚Ä¢ Why would a reasonable, rational, and decent person do what this person is doing? This particular question humanizes others. As we search for plausible answers to it, our emotions soften. Empathy often replaces judgment, and depending upon how we‚Äôve treated others, personal accountability replaces self-justification.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 Why would a reasonable, rational, and decent person do what this person is doing?

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 As we search for plausible answers to it, our emotions soften. Empathy often replaces judgment, and depending upon how we‚Äôve treated others, personal accountability replaces self-justification.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 But what if she really were a reasonable, rational, and decent person? What if she had no motive other than to give you a hand? Isn‚Äôt it a bit early to be vilifying her? And if you do, don‚Äôt you run the risk of ruining a relationship?

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 The purpose of the humanizing question is to deal with our own stories and emotions. It provides us with still another tool for working on ourselves first by providing a variety of possible reasons for the other person‚Äôs behavior.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 In fact, with experience and maturity we learn to worry less about others‚Äô intent and more about the effect others‚Äô actions are having on us.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 And here‚Äôs the good news. When we reflect on alternative motives, not only do we soften our emotions, but equally important, we relax our absolute certainty long enough to allow for dialogue‚Äî the only reliable way of discovering others‚Äô genuine motives.

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 Turn the helpless into the able. Finally, when you catch yourself bemoaning your own helplessness, you can tell the complete story by returning to your original motive. To do so, stop and ask:

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 What do I really want? For me? For others? For the relationship? Then, kill the Fool‚Äôs Choice that‚Äôs made you feel helpless to choose anything other than silence or violence. Do this by asking:

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 ‚Ä¢ What would I do right now if I really wanted these results?

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 What would I do right now if I really wanted these results?

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 When you refuse to make yourself helpless, you‚Äôre forced to hold yourself accountable for using your dialogue skills rather than bemoaning your weakness.

Yellow highlight | Page: 126 As we tell the rest of the story, we free ourselves from the poisoning effects of unhealthy emotions. Best of all, as we regain control and move back to dialogue, we become masters of our own emotions rather than hostages.

Yellow highlight | Page: 128 As soon as she shows signs of frustration, I stop and remind her that I am on her side.

Yellow highlight | Page: 131 So far we‚Äôve gone to great pains to prepare ourselves to step up to and master crucial conversations. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôve learned. Our hearts need to be in the right place. We need to pay close attention to crucial conversations‚Äîparticularly when people start feeling unsafe‚Äîand restore safety when necessary. And heaven forbid that we should tell ourselves clever and unhelpful stories.

Yellow highlight | Page: 131 Most of the time, we walk into a discussion and slide into autopilot. ‚ÄúHi, how are the kids? What‚Äôs going on at work?‚Äù What could be easier than talking? We know thousands of words and generally weave them into sentences that suit our needs. Most of the time.

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 However, when stakes rise and our emotions kick in, well, that‚Äôs when we open our mouths and don‚Äôt do so well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 In fact, as we suggested earlier, the more important the discussion, the less likely we are to be on our best behavior. More specifically, we advocate or express our views quite poorly.

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, Marta, but people simply don‚Äôt like working with you. You‚Äôve been asked to leave the special-projects team.‚Äù It‚Äôs one thing to argue that your company needs to shift from green to red packaging; it‚Äôs quite another to tell a person that he or she is offensive or unlikable. When the topic turns from things to people, it‚Äôs always more difficult, and to nobody‚Äôs surprise, some people are better at it than others.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 The best at dialogue speak their minds completely and do it in a way that makes it safe for others to hear what they have to say and respond to it as well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 They are both totally frank and completely respectful.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 if you know how to carefully blend three ingredients‚Äîconfidence, humility, and skill.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 People who are skilled at dialogue have the confidence to say what needs to be said to the person who needs to hear it. They are confident that their opinions deserve to be placed in the pool of meaning. They are also confident that they can speak openly without brutalizing others or causing undue offense.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 Skilled people are confident that they have something to say, but also realize that others have valuable input. They are humble enough to realize that they don‚Äôt have a monopoly on the truth nor do they always have to win their way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 This means they‚Äôre willing to both express their opinions and encourage others to do the same. Skill. Finally, people who willingly share delicate information are good at doing it. That‚Äôs why they‚Äôre confident in the first place. They don‚Äôt make a Fool‚Äôs Choice, because they‚Äôve found a path that allows for both candor and safety. They speak the unspeakable, and people are grateful for their honesty.

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 moving back to Australia)? What‚Äôs the worst way of talking about the problem? Most people agree that jumping in with an ugly accusation followed by a threat is a good candidate for that distinction. It‚Äôs also what most people do, and Carole is no exception.

Yellow highlight | Page: 136 Share your facts ‚Ä¢ Tell your story ‚Ä¢ Ask for others‚Äô paths ‚Ä¢ Talk tentatively ‚Ä¢ Encourage testing

Yellow highlight | Page: 137 Of course, starting with our ugly stories is the most controversial, least influential, and most insulting way we could begin.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 it. We hold it inside where the story builds up steam, and when we do eventually share our horrific story, we do so with a vengeance. The cycle starts all over again.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Facts are the least controversial. Facts provide a safe beginning. By their very nature, facts aren‚Äôt controversial. That‚Äôs why we call them facts. For example, consider the statement: ‚ÄúYesterday you arrived at work twenty minutes late.‚Äù No dispute there. Conclusions, on the other hand, are highly controversial. For example: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be trusted.‚Äù That‚Äôs hardly a fact. Actually, it‚Äôs more like an insult, and

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Facts are the most persuasive. In addition to being less controversial, facts are also more persuasive than subjective conclusions. Facts form the foundation of belief. So if you want to persuade others, don‚Äôt start with your stories. Start with your observations. For example, which of the following do you find more persuasive?

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 ‚ÄúI want you to stop sexually harassing me!‚Äù or ¬† ‚ÄúWhen you talk to me, your eyes move up and down rather than look at my face. And sometimes you put your hand on my shoulder.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 139 When we start with shocking or offensive conclusions (‚ÄúQuit groping me with your eyes!‚Äù or ‚ÄúI think we should declare bankruptcy‚Äù), we actually encourage others to tell Villain Stories about us. Since we‚Äôve given them no facts to

Yellow highlight | Page: 139 support our conclusion, they make up reasons we‚Äôre saying these things. They‚Äôre likely to believe we‚Äôre either stupid or evil.

Yellow highlight | Page: 139 And if you aren‚Äôt sure what your facts are (your story is absolutely filling your brain), take the time to think them through before you enter the crucial conversation. Take the time to sort out facts from conclusions. Gathering the facts is the homework required for crucial conversations. Facts are the least insulting. If you do want to share your story, don‚Äôt start with it. Your story (particularly if it has led to a rather ugly conclusion) could easily surprise and insult others. It could kill safety in one rash, ill-conceived sentence.

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 Begin your path with facts. In order to talk about your stories, you need to lead the others involved down your Path to Action. Let them experience your path from the beginning to the end, and not from the end to‚Äîwell, to wherever

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 Earn the right to share your story by starting with your facts. Facts lay the groundwork for all delicate conversations.

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 Sharing your story can be tricky. Even if you‚Äôve started with your facts, the other person can still become defensive when you move from facts to stories. After all, you‚Äôre sharing potentially unflattering conclusions and judgments.

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 (Sounds like it‚Äôs time for a conclusion.) ‚ÄúI was wondering what the software is doing in your briefcase. It looks like you‚Äôre taking it home. Is that what‚Äôs going on here?‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 It takes confidence. To be honest, it can be difficult to share negative conclusions and unattractive judgments (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôm wondering if you‚Äôre a thief‚Äù). It takes confidence to share such a potentially inflammatory story. However, if you‚Äôve done your homework by thinking through the facts behind your story, you‚Äôll realize that you are drawing

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 By thinking through the facts and then leading with them, you‚Äôre much more likely to have the confidence you need to add controversial and vitally important meaning to the shared pool.

Yellow highlight | Page: 142 Look for safety problems. As you share your story, watch for signs that safety is deteriorating. If people start becoming defensive or appear to be insulted, step out of the conversation and rebuild safety by Contrasting.

Yellow highlight | Page: 143 Be careful not to apologize for your views. Remember, the goal of Contrasting is not to water down your message, but to be sure that people don‚Äôt hear more than you intend. Be confident enough to share what you really want to

Yellow highlight | Page: 144 One of the ironies of dialogue is that, when talking with those holding opposing opinions, the more convinced and forceful you act, the more resistant others become. Speaking in absolute and overstated terms does not increase your influence, it decreases it. The converse is also true‚Äîthe more tentatively you speak, the more open people become to your opinions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 145 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs starting to look like you‚Äôre

Yellow highlight | Page: 145 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs leading me to conclude that you‚Äôre

Yellow highlight | Page: 145 starting to use drugs. Do you have another explanation that I‚Äôm missing

Yellow highlight | Page: 146 right: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm starting to feel like you don‚Äôt trust me. Is that what‚Äôs going on here? If so, I‚Äôd like to know what I did to lose your trust.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 146 Just right: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre intending this, but I‚Äôm beginning to feel rejected.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 146 Safety becomes particularly important when you‚Äôre having a crucial conversation with people who might move to silence. Some people make Fool‚Äôs Choices in these circumstances. They worry that if they share their true opinions, others will clam up. So they choose between speaking their minds and hearing others out. But the best at dialogue don‚Äôt choose. They do both. They understand that the only limit to how strongly you can express your opinion is your willingness to be equally vigorous in encouraging others to challenge

Yellow highlight | Page: 146 Invite opposing views. So if you think others may be hesitant, make it clear that you want to hear their views‚Äîno matter how different. If others disagree, so much the better.

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 ‚ÄúDoes anyone see it differently?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat am I missing here?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôd

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 really like to hear the other side of this story.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 Mean it. Sometimes people offer an invitation that sounds more like a threat than a legitimate call for opinions. ‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs how I see it. Nobody disagrees, do they?‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 Play devil‚Äôs advocate. Occasionally you can tell that others are not buying into your facts or story, but they‚Äôre not speaking up either. You‚Äôve sincerely invited them, even encouraged differing views, but nobody says anything. To help grease the skids, play devil‚Äôs advocate. Yellow highlight | Page: 150 It starts with a story. When we feel the need to push our ideas on others, it‚Äôs generally because we believe we‚Äôre right and everyone else is wrong. There‚Äôs no need to expand the pool of meaning, because we own the pool. We also firmly believe it‚Äôs our duty to fight for the truth that we‚Äôre holding. It‚Äôs the honorable thing to do. It‚Äôs what people of character do.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 We use debating tricks that we‚Äôve picked up throughout the years. Chief among them is the ability to ‚Äústack the deck.‚Äù We cite information that supports our ideas while hiding or discrediting anything that doesn‚Äôt.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 Then we spice things up with exaggeration: ‚ÄúEveryone knows that this is the only way to go.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 When this doesn‚Äôt work, we lace our language with inflammatory terms: ‚ÄúAll right-thinking people would agree with me.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 We draw hasty generalizations:

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 And again, the harder we try and the more forceful and nasty our tactics, the greater the resistance we create, the worse the results, and the more battered our relationships.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 When you find yourself just dying to convince others that your way is best, back off your current attack and think about what you really want for yourself, others, and the relationship. Then ask yourself, ‚ÄúHow would I behave if these were the results I really wanted?‚Äù When your adrenaline level gets below the 0.05 legal limit, you‚Äôll be able to use your STATE skills.

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 First, Learn to Look. Watch for the moment when people start to resist you‚Äîperhaps they begin to raise their volume and/or overstate the facts behind their views in reaction to your tactics‚Äîor perhaps they retreat into silence. Turn your attention away from the topic (no matter how important) and onto yourself. Are you leaning forward? Are you speaking more loudly? Are you starting to try to win? Are you speaking in lengthy monologues and using dirty tricks? Remember: The more you care about an issue, the less likely you are to be on your best behavior.

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 Of course, this isn‚Äôt easy. Backing off when we care the most is so counterintuitive that most of us have trouble doing so. It‚Äôs not easy to soften your language when you‚Äôre positive about something. And who wants to ask for other views when you know they‚Äôre wrong? That‚Äôs positively nuts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 Let‚Äôs face it. When it comes to our strongest views, passion can be our enemy. Of course, feeling strongly about something isn‚Äôt bad in and of itself. It‚Äôs okay to have strong opinions. The problem comes when we try to express them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 153 Catch yourself. So what‚Äôs a person to do? Catch yourself before you launch into a monologue. Realize that if you‚Äôre starting to feel indignant or if you can‚Äôt figure out why others don‚Äôt buy in‚Äîafter all, it‚Äôs so obvious to you‚Äîrecognize that you‚Äôre starting to enter dangerous territory. Back off your harsh and conclusive language. But don‚Äôt back off your belief. Hold to your belief; merely soften your approach.

Yellow highlight | Page: 157 when most people become furious, we need to become curious. Rather than respond in kind, we need to wonder what‚Äôs behind the ruckus.

Blue highlight | Page: 157 But how? How can we possibly act curious when others are either attacking us or heading for cover? People who routinely seek to find out why others are feeling unsafe do so because they have learned that getting at the source of fear and discomfort is the best way to return to dialogue.

Yellow highlight | Page: 157 Either they‚Äôve seen others do it or they‚Äôve stumbled on the formula themselves. Either way, they realize that the cure to silence or violence isn‚Äôt to respond in kind, but to get at the underlying source. This calls for genuine curiosity‚Äîat a time when you‚Äôre likely to be feeling frustrated or angry.

Blue highlight | Page: 158 Stay curious. When people begin to share their volatile stories and feelings, we now face the risk of pulling out our own Victim, Villain, and Helpless Stories to help us explain why they‚Äôre saying what they‚Äôre saying. Unfortunately, since it‚Äôs rarely fun to hear other people‚Äôs unflattering stories, we begin to assign negative motives to them for telling the stories. For example:

Blue highlight | Page: 159 To avoid overreacting to others‚Äô stories, stay curious. Give your brain a problem to stay focused on. Ask: ‚ÄúWhy would a reasonable, rational, and decent person say this?‚Äù This question keeps you retracing the other person‚Äôs Path to Action until you see how it all fits together. And in most

Blue highlight | Page: 159 Be patient. When others are acting out their feelings and opinions through silence or violence, it‚Äôs a good bet they‚Äôre starting to feel the effects of adrenaline. Even if we do our best to safely and effectively respond to the other person‚Äôs verbal attack, we still have to face up to the fact that it‚Äôs going to take a little while for him or her to settle down. Say, for example, that a friend dumps out an ugly story and you treat it with respect and continue on with the conversation. Even if the two of you now share a similar view, it may seem like your friend is still pushing too hard. While it‚Äôs natural to move quickly from one thought to the next, strong emotions take a while to subside. Once the chemicals that fuel emotions are released, they hang around in the bloodstream for a time‚Äîin some cases, long after thoughts have changed.

Blue highlight | Page: 159 So be patient when exploring how others think and feel. Encourage them to share their path and then wait for their emotions to catch up with the safety that you‚Äôve created.

Yellow highlight | Page: 159 Once you‚Äôve decided to maintain a curious approach, it‚Äôs time to help the other person retrace his or her Path to Action. Unfortunately, most of us fail to do so. That‚Äôs because when others start playing silence or violence games, we‚Äôre joining the conversation at the end of their Path to Action. They‚Äôve seen and heard things, told themselves a story or two, generated a feeling (possibly a mix of fear and anger or disappointment), and now they‚Äôre starting to act out their story. That‚Äôs where we come in. Now, even though we may be hearing their first words, we‚Äôre coming in somewhere near the end of their path. On the Path to
