Blue highlight | Page: 170 As you watch families and work groups take part in heated debates, it‚Äôs common to notice a rather intriguing phenomenon. Although the various parties you‚Äôre observing are violently arguing, in truth, they‚Äôre in violent agreement. They actually agree on every important point, but they‚Äôre still fighting. They‚Äôve found a way to turn subtle differences into a raging debate.

Blue highlight | Page: 171 Most arguments consist of battles over the 5 to 10 percent of the facts and stories that people disagree over. And while it‚Äôs true that people eventually need to work through differences, you shouldn‚Äôt start there. Start with an area of agreement.

Blue highlight | Page: 171 So here‚Äôs the take-away. If you completely agree with the other person‚Äôs path, say so and move on. Agree when you agree. Don‚Äôt turn an agreement into an argument.

Blue highlight | Page: 171 Of course, the reason most of us turn agreements into debates is because we disagree with a certain portion of what the other person has said. Never mind that it‚Äôs a minor portion. If it‚Äôs a point of disagreement, we‚Äôll jump all over it like a fleeing criminal.

Blue highlight | Page: 171 it first is even better. And of course, having it first after others are wrong endows you with an even greater glory! Over time you find that finding even the tiniest of errors in others‚Äô facts, thinking, or logic reinforces your supreme place in the spotlight of teacher and peer admiration. So you point out their errors. Being right at the expense of others becomes skillful sport.

Blue highlight | Page: 171 On the other hand, when you watch people who are skilled in dialogue, it becomes clear that they‚Äôre not playing this everyday game of Trivial Pursuit‚Äîlooking for trivial differences and then proclaiming them aloud. In fact, they‚Äôre looking for points of agreement. As a result, they‚Äôll often start with the words ‚ÄúI agree.‚Äù Then they talk about the part they agree with. At least, that‚Äôs where they start.

Blue highlight | Page: 172 Now when the other person has merely left out an element of the argument, skilled people will agree and then build. Rather than saying: ‚ÄúWrong. You forgot to mention . . .,‚Äù they say: ‚ÄúAbsolutely. In addition, I noticed that. .

Blue highlight | Page: 172 If you agree with what has been said but the information is incomplete, build. Point out areas of agreement, and

Blue highlight | Page: 172 then add elements that were left out of the discussion.

Blue highlight | Page: 172 Finally, if you do disagree, compare your path with the other person‚Äôs. That is, rather than suggesting that he or she is wrong, suggest that you differ. He or she may, in fact, be wrong, but you don‚Äôt know for sure until you hear both sides of the story. For now, you just know that the two of you differ. So instead of pronouncing ‚ÄúWrong!‚Äù start with a tentative but candid opening, such as ‚ÄúI think I see things differently. Let me describe how.‚Äù

Blue highlight | Page: 172 In summary, to help remember these skills, think of your ABCs. Agree when you agree. Build when others leave out key pieces. Compare when you differ. Don‚Äôt turn differences into debates that lead to unhealthy relationships and bad results.

Blue highlight | Page: 178 They have unclear expectations about how decisions will be made.

Blue highlight | Page: 179 Both of these problems are solved if, before making a decision, the people involved decide how to decide. Don‚Äôt allow people to assume that dialogue is decision making. Dialogue is a process for getting all relevant meaning into a shared pool. That process, of course, involves everyone. However, simply because everyone is allowed to share their meaning‚Äîactually encouraged to share their meaning‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt mean they are then guaranteed to take part in making all the decisions. To avoid violated expectations, separate dialogue from decision making. Make it clear how decisions will be made‚Äîwho will be involved and why.

Blue highlight | Page: 179 When the line of authority isn‚Äôt clear. When there is no clear line of authority, deciding how to decide can be quite difficult.

Blue highlight | Page: 180 Don‚Äôt mention lawyers or a lawsuit in your opening comments; this only reduces safety and sets up an adversarial climate.

Blue highlight | Page: 180 There are four common ways of making decisions: command, consult, vote, and consensus.

Blue highlight | Page: 181 Consulting is a process whereby decision makers invite others to influence them before they make their choice.

Blue highlight | Page: 182 Consensus This method can be both a great blessing and a frustrating curse. Consensus means you talk until everyone honestly agrees to one decision. This method can produce tremendous unity and high-quality decisions. If misapplied, it can also be a horrible waste of time. It should only be used with (1) high-stakes and complex issues or (2) issues where everyone absolutely must support the final choice.

Blue highlight | Page: 184 Be sure to spell out the exact deliverables you have in mind. The fuzzier the expectations, the higher the likelihood of disappointment.

Blue highlight | Page: 185 assignment, clarify up front the exact details of what you want. Couples get into trouble in this area when one of the parties doesn‚Äôt want to take the time to think carefully about the ‚Äúdeliverables‚Äù and then later on becomes upset because his or her unstated desires weren‚Äôt met. Have you ever remodeled a room with a loved one? Then you know what we‚Äôre talking about. Better to spend the time up front clarifying exactly what you want rather than waste resources and hurt feelings on the back end.

Blue highlight | Page: 186 It‚Äôs shocking how often people leave this element out of an assignment. Instead of giving a deadline, people simply point to the setting sun of ‚Äúsomeday.‚Äù With vague or unspoken deadlines, other urgencies come up, and the assignment finds its way to the bottom of the pile, where it is soon forgotten. Assignments without deadlines are far better at producing guilt than stimulating action. Goals without deadlines aren‚Äôt goals; they‚Äôre merely directions.

Blue highlight | Page: 186 Remember, if you want people to feel accountable, you must give them an opportunity to account. Build an expectation for follow-up into every assignment.

Blue highlight | Page: 186 Once again, a proverb comes to mind. ‚ÄúOne dull pencil is worth six sharp minds.‚Äù

In an article largely overlooked since it was published in 2002, they described how they were able to draw website visitors‚Äô attention to the goal of comfort merely by placing fluffy clouds on the background wallpaper of the site‚Äôs landing page. That maneuver led those visitors to assign elevated levels of importance to comfort when asked what they were looking for in a sofa. Those same visitors also became more likely to search the site for information about the comfort features of the sofas in stock and, most notably, to choose a more comfortable (and more costly) sofa as their preferred purchase. Yellow highlight | Page: 37 Core messages help people avoid bad choices by reminding them of what‚Äôs important.

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 If remembering was like weight lifting, it would be ridiculous to think we could ‚Äúlift‚Äù JFK easier than three little letters!

In the end, it‚Äôs one bit of information (or one flag) versus three, and it‚Äôs no surprise that one is easier to remember.

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 The first problem of communication is getting people‚Äôs attention.

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 The most basic way to get someone‚Äôs attention is this: Break a pattern. Humans adapt incredibly quickly to consistent patterns.

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 Our brain is designed to be keenly aware of changes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 when products require users to pay attention, something changes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 This chapter focuses on two essential questions: How do I get people‚Äôs attention? And, just as crucially, How do I keep it?

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 To understand the answers to these two questions, we have to understand two essential emotions‚Äîsurprise and interest‚Äîthat are commonly provoked by naturally sticky ideas.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 Our schemas are like guessing machines. Schemas help us predict what will happen and, consequently, how we should make decisions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 Emotions are elegantly tuned to help us deal with critical situations.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 For instance, a secondary effect of being angry, which was recently discovered by researchers, is that we become more certain of our judgments. When we‚Äôre angry, we know we‚Äôre right, as anyone who has been in a relationship can attest.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 So if emotions have biological purposes, then what is the biological purpose of surprise? Surprise jolts us to attention. Surprise is triggered when our schemas fail, and it prepares us to understand why the failure occurred. When our guessing machines fail, surprise grabs our attention so that we can repair them for the future.

Yellow highlight | Page: 68 a book called Unmasking the Face, Paul Ekman and Wallace Friesen coined a term, ‚Äúthe surprise brow,‚Äù to

Yellow highlight | Page: 68 When our brows go up, it widens our eyes and gives us a broader field of vision‚Äîthe surprise brow is our body‚Äôs way of forcing us to see more.

Yellow highlight | Page: 68 Unexpected ideas are more likely to stick because surprise makes us pay attention and think.

Yellow highlight | Page: 68 Surprise can prompt us to hunt for underlying causes, to imagine other possibilities, to figure out how to avoid surprises in the future.

Blue highlight | Page: 83 McKee says, ‚ÄúCuriosity11 is the intellectual need to answer questions and close open patterns. Story plays to this universal desire by doing the opposite, posing questions and opening situations.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 83 In McKee‚Äôs view, a great script is designed so that every scene is a Turning Point. ‚ÄúEach Turning Point hooks curiosity. The audience wonders, What will happen next? and How will it turn out?

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 In 1994, George Loewenstein,12 a behavioral economist at Carnegie Mellon University, provided the most comprehensive account of situational interest. It is surprisingly simple. Curiosity, he says, happens when we feel a gap in our knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 Loewenstein argues that gaps cause pain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 ‚ÄúStory works by posing questions and opening situations.‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 Pok√©mon cards cause kids to wonder, Which characters am I missing?

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 One important implication of the gap theory is that we need to open gaps before we close them. Our tendency is to tell people the facts. First, though, they must realize that they need these facts. The trick to convincing people that they need our message, according to Loewenstein, is to first highlight some specific knowledge that they‚Äôre missing. We can pose a question or puzzle that confronts people with a gap in their knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 We can point out that someone else knows something they don‚Äôt. We can present them with situations that have unknown resolutions, such as elections, sports events, or mysteries. We can challenge them to predict an outcome (which creates two knowledge gaps‚ÄîWhat will happen? and Was I right?).

Blue highlight | Page: 85 They work because they tease you with something that you don‚Äôt know‚Äîin fact, something that you didn‚Äôt care about at all, until you found out that you didn‚Äôt know it. ‚ÄúIs my daughter strung out on one of my old prescriptions? I wonder if I ate at the restaurant with the slime?

Blue highlight | Page: 86 In improving this message, we need to think about how to elicit interest rather than force-feeding facts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 This approach is inspired by the gap theory. The goal is not to summarize; it‚Äôs to make you care about knowing something, and then to tell you what you want to know.

Blue highlight | Page: 87 The improvement here is driven by structure, not content. Let‚Äôs face it, this is not a particularly interesting mystery. It would never make an episode of Law & Order. But our minds are extremely generous when it comes to mysteries‚Äîthe format is inherently appealing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 The news-teaser approach can be used with all sorts of ideas in all sorts of contexts. To make our communications more effective, we need to shift our thinking from ‚ÄúWhat information do I need to convey?‚Äù to ‚ÄúWhat questions do I want my audience to ask?‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 know. One complication is that people tend to think they know a lot.

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 If people believe they know everything, it‚Äôs hard to make the gap theory work. Fortunately, there are strategies for combating overconfidence. For instance, Nora Ephron‚Äôs journalism teacher prevented overconfidence by causing the students‚Äô schemas of journalism to fail. He made them commit to their preconceived ideas and then pulled the rug out from under them.

Blue highlight | Page: 88 Making people commit to a prediction can help prevent overconfidence.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 Eric Mazur, a physics professor at Harvard, came up with a pedagogical innovation known as ‚Äúconcept testing.‚Äù Every so often in his classes, Mazur will pose a conceptual question and then ask his students to vote publicly on the answer. The simple act of committing to an answer makes the students more engaged and more curious about the outcome.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 The thirst to fill a knowledge gap‚Äîto find out who was right‚Äîcan be more powerful than the thirst for slides and jungle gyms.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 If curiosity arises from knowledge gaps, we might assume that when we know more, we‚Äôll become less curious because there are fewer gaps in our knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 But Loewenstein argues that the opposite is true. He says that as we gain

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 information we are more and more likely to focus on what we don‚Äôt know. Someone who knows the state capitals of 17 of 50 states may be proud of her knowledge. But someone who knows 47 may be more likely to think of herself as not knowing 3 capitals.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 Human-interest stories are fascinating because we know what it‚Äôs like to be human‚Äîbut we don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs like to have certain dramatic experiences.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 Gossip is popular because we know a lot about some people but there‚Äôs some information that we lack.

Yellow highlight | Page: 91 Arledge intuitively made use of Loewenstein‚Äôs gap theory. How do you get people interested in a topic? You point out a gap in their knowledge. But what if they lack so much knowledge about, say, the Georgia Bulldogs, that they‚Äôve got more of an abyss than a gap? In that case, you have to fill in enough knowledge to make the abyss into a gap.

Pink highlight | Page: 107 Yale researcher Eric Havelock3 studies tales that have been passed down by word of mouth, such as the Iliad and the Odyssey. He notes that these tales are characterized by lots of concrete actions, with few abstractions. Why? The ancient Greeks certainly had no problem with abstraction‚Äîthis was the society that produced Plato and Aristotle, after all. Havelock believes that the stories evolved away from abstraction over time. When they were passed along from generation to generation, the more memorable concrete details survived and the abstractions evaporated.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 The Curse of Knowledge is a worthy adversary, because in some sense it‚Äôs inevitable. Getting a message across has two stages: the Answer stage and the Telling Others stage. In the Answer stage, you use your expertise to arrive at the idea that you want to share. Doctors study for a decade to be capable of giving the Answer. Business managers may deliberate for months to arrive at the Answer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 Here‚Äôs the rub: The same factors that worked to your advantage in the Answer stage will backfire on you during the Telling Others stage. To get the Answer, you need expertise, but you can‚Äôt dissociate expertise from the Curse of Knowledge. You know things that others don‚Äôt know, and you can‚Äôt remember what it was like not to know those things. So when you get around to sharing the Answer, you‚Äôll tend to communicate as if your audience were you.

Pink highlight | Location: 628 The effects of this activation are well-known. The body is no longer concerned with living ten more years, but with surviving ten more minutes. It shuts down nonurgent functions such as muscle repair, digestion, and the immune system,

Yellow highlight | Page: 227 Planning vs.¬†perceiving. Some people like to live in a planned, orderly way and others prefer flexibility and spontaneity.35 Planners (or ‚ÄúJudgers‚Äù in Myers-Briggs terms) like to focus on a plan and stick with it, while perceivers are prone to focus on what‚Äôs happening around them and adapt to it. Perceivers work from the outside in; they see things happening and work backward to understand the cause and how to respond; they also see many possibilities that they compare and choose from‚Äîoften so many that they are confused by them. In contrast, planners work from the inside out, first figuring out what they want to achieve and then how things should unfold. Planners and perceivers have trouble appreciating each other. Perceivers see new things and change direction often. This is discomforting to planners, who weigh precedent much more heavily in their decision making, and assume if it was done in a certain way before, it should be done in the same way again. Similarly, planners can discomfort perceivers by being seemingly rigid and slow to adapt.

Yellow highlight | Page: 228 Creators generate new ideas and original concepts. They prefer unstructured and abstract activities and thrive on innovation and unconventional practices.

All too often negotiators ‚Äúleave money on the table‚Äù ‚Äî they fail to reach agreement when they might have, or the agreement they do reach could have been better for each side. Too many negotiations end up with half an orange for each side instead of the whole fruit for one and the whole peel for the other. Why?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,887 Ask questions and pause. Those engaged in negotiation jujitsu use two key tools. The first is to use questions instead of statements.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,893 Silence is one of your best weapons. Use it. If they have made an unreasonable proposal or an attack you regard as unjustified, the best thing to do may be to sit there and not say a word.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,894 If you have asked an honest question to which they have provided an insufficient answer, just wait. People tend to feel uncomfortable with silence, particularly if they have doubts about the merits of something they have said.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,899 Silence often creates the impression of a stalemate that the other side will feel impelled to break by answering your question or coming up with a new suggestion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,900 When you ask questions, pause. Don‚Äôt take them off the hook by going right on with another question or some comment of your own. Some of the most effective negotiating you will ever do is when you are not talking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,967 that a camel is a horse designed by a committee.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,973 Note that in most situations you do not have to get anyone‚Äôs consent to start using the one-text procedure.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,974 Simply prepare a draft and ask for criticism.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,992 The essence of principled negotiation lies in remaining open to persuasion by objective facts and principles.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,000 Making yourself open to correction and persuasion is a pillar in the strategy of principled negotiation. You can convince the other side to be open to the principles and objective standards you suggest only if you show yourself open to the ones they suggest.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,002 ‚ÄúWe appreciate what you‚Äôve done for us‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,007 ‚ÄúWe have nothing against you personally. We think you‚Äôre a generous person.‚Äù He puts himself on her side. He defuses any threat she may feel to her self-image.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,008 Praise and support, moreover, imply that the person will continue to deserve them. After being praised, Mrs.¬†Jones now has a slight emotional investment in Turnbull‚Äôs approval of her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,011 ‚ÄúOur concern is fairness‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,014 Turnbull takes a basic stand on principle and announces his intention to stick to it;

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,015 he must be persuaded on the basis of principle. At the same time, he lets Mrs.¬†Jones know he is open to persuasion along the lines of this principle. She is thus left with little choice but to reason with him in pursuit of her interests.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,018 His ends, he claims, are a fair balance between rent paid and time spent.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,020 ‚ÄúWe would like to settle this on the basis of independent standards, not of who can do what to whom‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,035 But instead of reacting, Turnbull keeps his temper and brings the negotiation back to the merits. This is a good example of negotiation jujitsu. He deflects Mrs.¬†Jones‚Äôs attack by taking responsibility for her mistaken perceptions, and he tries to persuade her of his sincere interest in principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,037 He does not hide either his selfish interests or his leverage over her; on the contrary, he makes both explicit. Once they are acknowledged, he can distinguish them from the merits and they can cease being an issue.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,047 however, by expressing his gratitude once more and then defining the question of trust as irrelevant. Turnbull at once reaffirms his appreciation of Mrs.¬†Jones while he remains firm on the principle. In doing so, he avoids connecting the two thoughts with ‚Äúbut,‚Äù implicitly using ‚Äúand‚Äù instead. ‚ÄúBut,‚Äù sometimes called the ‚Äúgreat eraser,‚Äù has a tendency to negate the first thing you say by implying that only one of two statements can be true, making it either/or. ‚ÄúAnd‚Äù underscores the more complex reality that both thoughts can be true at the same time.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,065 Analysis. Statements of fact can feel lecturing or threatening. Whenever you can, ask a question instead.

Note:important

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,069 Phrasing each piece of information as a question allows Mrs.¬†Jones to participate, listen to the information, evaluate it, and either accept or correct it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,070 Turnbull communicates the same information to her but in a less provocative manner. He reduces the heat still further by attributing a particularly pointed question to his absent roommate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,076 A principled negotiator neither accepts nor rejects the other side‚Äôs positions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,076 To keep the dialogue focused on the merits, Turnbull questions Mrs.¬†Jones about the reasons for her position. He does not ask whether there were any reasons. He assumes there are good reasons. This flattering assumption leads the other side to search for reasons even if there are none, thus keeping the negotiation on the basis of principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,086 Analysis. Principled negotiation requires good communication. Before responding to Mrs.¬†Jones‚Äôs arguments, Turnbull restates to her in positive terms what he has heard to make sure he has indeed understood her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,087 Once she feels understood, she can relax and discuss the problem constructively.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,088 She can‚Äôt dismiss his arguments on the grounds that they do not take into account what she knows. She is more likely to listen now and be more receptive. In trying to sum up her point of view, Turnbull establishes a cooperative game in which both are making sure he understands the facts.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,093 Analysis. A good negotiator rarely makes an important decision on the spot. The psychological pressure to be nice and to give in is too great. A little time and distance help disentangle the people from the problem.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,097 He shows not only decisiveness but also control over the course of the negotiation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,103 Turnbull: Let me show you where I have trouble following some of your reasons for the extra $268 a month.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,108 Analysis. In principled negotiation you present your reasons first before offering a proposal. If principles come afterward, they appear not as the objective criteria that any proposal should satisfy but as mere justifications for an arbitrary position.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,110 For Turnbull to explain his reasons first shows his openness to persuasion and his awareness of the need to convince Mrs.¬†Jones. If he announced his proposal first, Mrs.¬†Jones probably would not bother to listen to the reasons that followed. Her mind would be elsewhere, considering what objections and counterproposals she could make.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,114 In preparing for your negotiation, it helps to think about what standards would be useful, who might be able to provide them, and how to frame your questions to elicit the most relevant information.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,116 ‚ÄúOne fair solution might be ‚Ä¶‚Äù

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,120 Analysis. Turnbull presents a proposal not as his, but as a fair option that deserves their joint consideration.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,120 He does not claim it is the only fair solution, but one fair solution. He is specific without digging himself into a position and inviting rejection.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,127 Turnbull is trying to make it easy for Mrs.¬†Jones to say yes to his proposal. So he starts by making it clear that all it takes for the problem to go away is Mrs.¬†Jones‚Äôs agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,130 without upsetting the negotiations? He bases the alternative on objective principle by attributing it to a legal authority‚Äîthe hearing examiner.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,131 He distances himself personally from the suggestion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,144 Incorporating her interests into the agreement not only gives her more of a stake in it but also allows Mrs.¬†Jones to save face.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,148 Paul and I do appreciate, Mrs.¬†Jones, all that you‚Äôve done for us, and I‚Äôm pleased that we‚Äôve settled this last problem fairly and amicably.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,194 Don‚Äôt attack people personally for using a tactic you consider illegitimate. If they get defensive it may be more difficult for them to give up the tactic, and they may be left with a residue of anger that will fester and interfere with other issues.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,198 Don‚Äôt be diverted from the negotiation by the urge to teach them a lesson.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,202 Invent options for mutual gain. Suggest alternative games to play. ‚ÄúHow about our undertaking

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,204 Insist on using objective criteria. Above

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,212 Some common tricky tactics Tricky tactics can be divided into three categories: deliberate deception, psychological warfare, and positional pressure

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,223 A practice of verifying factual assertions reduces the incentive for deception, and your risk of being cheated.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,450 expected. In contrast, looking behind positions for interests, inventing options for mutual gain, and finding and using objective criteria take hard work and, when the other side seems recalcitrant, emotional restraint and maturity.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,461 How complex are the issues? The more complex the subject matter, the more unwise it is to engage in positional bargaining. Complexity calls for careful analysis of interests that are shared or that can be creatively dovetailed, and then for brainstorming.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,463 How important is it to maintain a good working relationship? If the other side is a valued customer or client, maintaining your ongoing relationship may be more important to you than the outcome of any one deal. This does not mean you should be less persistent in pursuing your interests, but it does suggest avoiding tactics such as threats or ultimatums that involve a high

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,482 Bargaining over positions does the least harm if it comes after you have identified each other‚Äôs interests, invented options for mutual gain, and discussed relevant standards of fairness.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,486 Yet using external standards improves on haggling in three ways: An outcome informed even by conflicting standards of fairness and community practice is likely to be wiser than an arbitrary result.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,506 Using external standards often helps narrow the range of disagreement and may help expand the area of potential agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,527 Many negotiators are overly optimistic in assuming that they are more clever than their counterparts.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,548 The human propensity for defensive and reactive behavior is one reason so many negotiations fail when agreement would otherwise make sense.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,551 The more seriously you disagree with someone, the more important it is that you be able to deal well with that disagreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,561 Rather, substantive issues need to be disentangled from relationship and process issues. The content of a possible agreement needs to be separated from questions of how you talk about it and how you deal with the other side. Each set of issues needs to be negotiated on its own merits. The following list illustrates the distinction: Substantive Issues Terms Conditions Prices Dates Numbers Liabilities Relationship Issues Balance of emotion and reason Ease of communication Degree of trust and reliability Attitude of acceptance (or rejection) Relative emphasis on persuasion (or coercion) Degree of mutual understanding People often assume that there is a trade-off between pursuing a good substantive outcome and pursuing a good relationship. We disagree. A good working relationship tends to make it easier to get good substantive outcomes (for both sides). Good substantive outcomes tend to make a good relationship even better.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,575 Our point is that you should not give in for the purpose of trying to improve a relationship.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,587 Our behavior should be designed to model and encourage the behavior we would prefer and to avoid any reward for the behavior we dislike, both without compromising our substantive interests.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,600 It is the perception that is skewed, not the response to that perception.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,601 On the other hand, if you inquire empathetically, taking their feelings seriously and trying to trace their reasoning to its roots, it is sometimes possible to effect change.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,603 Working with them, you may discover a logical leap, a factual misperception, or a traumatic association from an earlier time that, once brought to light, can be examined and modified by the people themselves.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,604 In essence, you are looking for the psychological interests behind their position, to help them find a way to meet more of their interests more effectively.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,656 A key point, worth repeating, is that negotiating does not require compromising your principles. More often success is achieved by finding a solution that is arguably consistent with each side‚Äôs principles.
